article.value: Introduction

On Sunday, 4 Jul 1946, the grandstand at the Luneta was festooned in red, white, and blue buntings for a historic ceremony. A tall flagpole flew the American flag and below waiting to be raised was the Philippine flag, designed during the Philippine Revolution against Spain. Weather was changeable. A slight shower dampened the hopes for a sunny day, but before noon, the sun came out and shone brightly. At noon, American High Commissioner William McNutt lowered the American flag while Pres Manuel A. Roxas raised the Philippine flag. Then, the weather turned foul; by the afternoon it was raining.

The era of the Third Republic began in 1946 with the declaration of Philippine independence from the United States. Immediately, the new republic faced the daunting task of rising from the devastation of World War II. Destruction was massive; along with its environs, Manila was the second most destroyed urban center in the world.

Reconstruction set the tone for the second half of the 1940s and the early half of the 1950s. After the war, all the public institutions, especially government, the Church, schools, businesses, transportation, communication, and power were challenged to rebuild. Reconstruction followed two paths. The first was to reconstruct what had been damaged during World War II—this may be called restoration. Restoration involved returning to the past before the war and establishing continuity between the past and the present. The massive destruction, however, in both Manila and the provinces had another face. It opened opportunities for new development and the introduction of the emerging International Style. The second path was to begin new projects in areas where little had been built. This second path would gain ground toward the second half of the 1950s.

Funds for reconstruction came partly from the war reparations from Japan and support from the United States, in the form of the Philippine Rehabilitation Act, sponsored by American senator Millard E. Tydings, which the United States Congress passed in Apr 1946. The Tydings Rehabilitation Act disbursed an initial $120 million for the rehabilitation of public buildings and infrastructure. The Philippines’s Bureau of Public Works collaborated with an office set up by the United States, the Bureau of Public Roads. The rehabilitation act had conditions which bound the Philippines more closely with the US. Americans were given parity rights to develop and exploit the Philippines’ natural resources and run public utilities just like any Filipino citizen. The United States also built large military bases in the Philippines, notably at Subic, Zambales and at Clark Field in Angeles, Pampanga.

The War Damage Rehabilitation Fund was set up to assess losses and distribute funds. It benefited both the public and the private sector. Funds were dispersed in the form of back pay for members of the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), through which Americans and Filipinos engaged hand in hand in combat during World War II. Financial help was also given to strategic private institutions like schools, churches, and factories.

With these funds, the newly established Philippine Republic had to prioritize the buildings it needed to function as government. Soon after the war, government buildings were reconstructed in accordance with their original plans, if funding allowed it. When funding was inadequate, the original plans were simplified as had been the case with the Legislative Building in Manila. The reconstruction phase lasted up to the 1950s. But these funds were not sufficient to address the damaged left by the war. When the Apostolic Delegate, William Piani, organized the Catholic Welfare Organization (CWO) to address the needs of the Catholic Church in the Philippines in the post-World War II era, the organization had to raise funds from private donors to support Church projects because war damage funds were insufficient. Later, the organization evolved to coordinate and organize Catholics in addressing educational, social welfare, religious, and spiritual issues under the bishops. Its constitution was approved by the Vatican on 28 Jun 1952 and in 1968, after Vatican II, it was reorganized as the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines (CBCP).

Reconstruction also meant ad hoc, piecemeal solutions to address the urgent needs for housing, infrastructure, and sanitation that would bring the Philippines back to normalcy. However, some of these solutions would lay the ground for future problems, such as the rise of informal settlements in urban centers and migration to urban centers. Attendant problems of overpopulation of certain areas, inadequacy of road systems, increase of traffic, degradation of peace and order, and breakdown of social services plagued and continue to plague the Philippines.

But the government, some institutions, and private individuals opted to take the second path of opening new developments and building more modern structures away from the traditional urban centers to new areas.
The most ambitious project and biggest government project was the conceptualization and construction of a new capital away from the original Burnham plan centered around Luneta.

In 1946, a new capital which would veer away from the vestiges of the colonial past and proclaim publicly the Filipino character of the new republic was envisioned in Quezon City. A 7,627-hectare area was chosen near the La Mesa Reservoir to allow for future expansion and for wide roads that could accommodate thousands. Pres Roxas through Administrative Order No 5 of 23 Jul 1946 established the Capital Site Committee. The following year Filipino architects were sent abroad for a study tour of capitals in the United States and Central and South America. Brasilia was especially influential in shaping the imagination of the Filipino architects which included Juan Arellano, Juan Nakpil, Cesar Concio, and engineer Manuel Mañosa Jr.

Roxas’s untimely death at Clark Field did not stop the pursuit of the project. Under his successor Elpidio Quirino, Republic Act No 333, enacted 17 Jul 1948, created Quezon City as the new capital city and for this, the Capital City Planning Commission was tasked with producing a master plan. The following year on 22 October, ground was broken at the highest point of the site, Constitution Hill, for the capitol building. An 11-story steel frame was built for the House of Representatives, designed by Felix Mendoza, but in 1960 construction stopped for lack of funds. The proposed Capital City remained dead on paper. On 24 Jun 1976, Presidential Decree No 940 reverted the capital to Manila and in 1978 the Batasang Pambansa, the unicameral legislature of the martial law years was inaugurated using the steel frame of the long abandoned capitol building in Quezon City.

The plan for a new capital fell within an established practice of more than three centuries where town planning and architecture were subsumed as part of the task of defining and projecting the state. The Spanish already harnessed the potential of planning when they built towns and cities according to the guidelines of the Laws of the Indies. Daniel Burnham’s master plans for Manila and Baguio and, later, the plans by the Bureau of Public Works for Cebu defined the new center under American control. Now it was the turn of an independent Philippines to project its own image and vision through concrete and steel in Quezon City.

article.value: Planned Communities and Suburbia. Addressing the need for post-World War II housing, planned communities arose in the municipalities and cities surrounding Manila. Both the private sector and government contributed to the development of these new projects. Such communities are called suburban or suburbia. But the terms are relational. Makati, Quezon City, and Pasay in the 1950s were suburbs of Manila. Now they are part of Metro Manila and communities referred to as suburban are in places like Valenzuela, Alabang, and Santa Rosa, Laguna.

The concept of planned communities was not altogether new. In pre-World War II days, New Manila was opened as a residential area for the elite, where lot sizes were no smaller than 1,000 sqm and where property owners could buy lots as large as one hectare. New Manila was on an elevated area of Quezon City, filled with trees, many of them fruit trees. It was envisioned as a pleasant garden village for the privileged. In 1931, Ayala y Compañia tranformed 930 ha of the Hacienda Makati into an integrated residential and business center under a 25-year plan. The elite residential area was known as Forbes Park.

Under Pres Manuel Quezon, the People’s Homesite Corporation (PHC) was created on 13 Oct 1938. Its charter mandated that housing be developed for low-income families. Land of 1,600 ha was purchased from the Diliman estate owned by Doña Teresa Tuason at the price of five centavos a square meter. Two million pesos were appropriated for the project but in 1941, when World War II began, the project came to a standstill.

The National Housing Corporation (NHC) was created in Sep 1945, and its first project came to be known as Heroes Hill in Quezon City. A 38.8-hectare-lot with a road network of five streets had 55 detached residences was made for the officials of the Philippine War Damage Commission and the Joint US Military Advisory Group (JUSMAG). NHC and PHC were merged on 9 Oct 1947 and became People’s Homesite and Housing Corporation (PHHC). Under the leadership of Anselmo T. Alquinto, what came to be known as Projects were commenced. Alquinto was a graduate of Harvard in town planning and landscape architecture, having been sent by the government as a pensionado or scholar before World War II. He designed the Projects as communities with low-cost bungalows, mass-produced and partially pre-fabricated. These were built on large tracts of land in Quezon City. Project 1 in the Roxas District was completed in 1949. Project 2 in Quirino was completed in 1951. Then followed by Projects 3 and 4 near Aurora Blvd and Anonas, and 5, 6, 7, and 8 in other parts of Quezon City. Project 16 was built in Caloocan.

Initially, these communities were “bedroom communities;” that is, residents went home to sleep and then commuted to Manila where they worked or studied. An initial reluctance to transfer to the projects was common because Quezon City was perceived as far away and public transportation was inadequate. Although these new projects were far more agreeable places to live in because they were surrounded by greenbelts and had ample lots for residents to plant trees and gardens, still it was a task to travel to and from them.

But that would change as the decades moved on. The University of the Philippines (UP), which had opened the Diliman Campus before World War II, expanded its facilities. The Ateneo de Manila did not rebuild in Intramuros but transferred its elementary, secondary, and tertiary units to Loyola Heights, leaving in Ermita its School of Law and Graduate School. Maryknoll College soon moved in next door to Ateneo and in the late 1950s, the Araneta Center was established in Cubao, with its iconic building the Araneta Coliseum being completed in 1959. By the 1960s, Quezon City had all the trappings of a modern city and became the preferred residential area as business and retail moved away from the historical sites of Binondo and Escolta.

article.value: Private Sector Development. Ayala y Compañia opened new villages first in Singalong, Manila right after World War II, then in Makati, where they followed a different scheme. The developer subdivided land, set aside an area for common amenities like a shopping mall or village clubhouse, but left the design and construction of the houses up to the owners subject to restrictions regarding height, percentage of the land that can be built and left as gardens, easement between the lot perimeter and the road and adjacent lots, even the minimum cost of construction. Thus, three Makati villages assumed a hierarchy. Prewar Forbes Park, which had a reputation as millionaires’ row had Dasmariñas Village built beside it as an extension. Between 1952 and 1962, San Lorenzo and Bel-Air were developed for the middle class. San Miguel was originally intended for the employees of San Miguel Corporation. Urdaneta was developed as an upper- middle class village between San Lorenzo and Forbes.

What differentiated post-World War II planned communities from earlier ones was that these communities provided space for public facilities like schools, clinics, markets, playgrounds, and business and retail area. In effect, they were being built as autonomous villages within the ambit of the urban center. Clubhouses and churches were built with the cooperation of the residents who organized themselves as village associations tasked with planning communal activities and building and maintaining common facilities. The association collected a yearly fee and had annual elections for officers following a constitution and bylaws crafted by the association.

Another privately initiated project was Philamlife Homes in Quezon City, a 600-unit housing project for middle-income families. It was an architectural highlight of the 1950s. The units, designed by Tomas Arguelles, were the result of thorough research and scientific study. While the comfort of the occupants was the chief consideration, the architect saw to it that construction would be economical and could be rapidly undertaken. From one basic idea came three typical units, each of which allowed four variants, making a total of 12 different schemes. Although compact in plan, the units enjoyed natural ventilation and had provisions for expansion. Since the inauguration of the project more than 30 years ago, most of the houses have undergone a metamorphosis.

Both Philam and the Ayala Villages were surrounded by a perimeter wall and entrance was restricted by guarded gates. The gated community proliferated and quickly became a symbol of social status. It was, after all, better maintained and its residents kept secure. But the gated community also had a downside. It excluded many others and stood in contrast to the shantytowns that had grown as a result of World War II and persisted until the 21st century.
As more residential villages were created, more roads had to be constructed made to link these new developments to the urban center feeder roads.

Business Districts. Reconstruction after World War II, the development of Makati beginning in the 1950s, and the emergence of new architects led to more imaginative and adventurous approaches to the design of office buildings.

The first of Makati office buildings to exceed the old 30-meter limit on height, the Insular Life Building curves grandly along the intersection of Ayala Ave and Paseo de Roxas and is veiled with sun-breaks. On the lower part of its facade is a bas-relief mural depicting aspects of Philippine life.

Ayala’s development of a business and commericial area along Ayala Ave, Makati Ave, Paseo de Roxas, and Pasay Road in the 1960s spurred the transfer of many companies to Makati. In the lead were the Ayalas who had Insular Life and Bank of the Philippine Islands head offices in the Escolta transferred to Ayala Ave, Makati. Likewise, the development of government projects and residential villages in Quezon City spurred the transfer of business and retail to Quezon City, especially when Cubao was developed by the Araneta family.

Presently called Araneta Center, this 35-hectare property area was purchased in 1952 by entrepreneur and sugar magnate from Negros, J. Amado Araneta from the Radio Corporation of America (RCA). Bounded by Aurora Blvd to the north, P. Tuazon to the south, Gen Romulo Ave to the east, and Epifanio de los Santos Ave (EDSA, formerly Highway 54) to the west, the property included the Araneta family home, called “Bahay na Puti” (White House), and a planned commercial area. Anchoring the development was the construction of a two-story rental space along Aurora Blvd. But what spurred rapid development in this area was Araneta Coliseum, begun in 1957 and was completed in late 1959. Graduates of Mapua Institute of Technology, architect Dominador Lacson Lugtu and engineer Leonardo Onjunco Lugtu designed the coliseum. Its iconic dome was constructed by assembling prefabricated arches that were bound together by a ring at the top. The roof structure rested on a solid drum of reinforced concrete and strong pillars anchored to the adobe substrate of Cubao. The coliseum became an iconic building in Quezon City. As sports and other forms of entertainment were held at the Coliseum, Cubao became a favorite destination and spurred development in the area.

The transfer to newer areas eventually led to the decline of Escolta and Binondo as vital players in the economy. By the 1970s, many buildings in these areas were either partially occupied or already abandoned which led to their deterioration.

Exploiting Reinforced Concrete. A better grasp of the possibilities of reinforced concrete led to the more extensive use of cantilevers, shell construction, and folded plate construction, and to a wider range of architectural forms. With pre-stressed concrete beams or post tensioning, vast interior spaces with no intervening posts could be created. Concrete was the material par excellence, not only for its strength but also for its plasticity. It enabled the architect to approach the task of architectural design not only as a planner but also as a sculptor.

With the strength assured by structural steel and steel bars, buildings could go beyond the height limit imposed by the building regulations. Until the 1950s the height of buildings was restricted by law to 30 m. Research on the ordinance revealed that the original reason for the limit was not earthquakes or the load-bearing strength of the soil, but the height that water could reach under natural pressure, made irrelevant by new technology. In 1960, Manila’s Building Ordinance No 4131 was amended to permit the construction of buildings up to a height of 45 m. Thus began the race towards the sky a challenging adventure for the Filipino architect and his inseparable associate, the structural engineer.

With the contest of height came the contest of size. While condominiums and office buildings began to take pride in their height, shopping malls came to glory in sheer expanse, measured in hundreds of thousands of square meters. Notable amidst all these were the expansion and liberation of artistic or architectural imagination and its happy marriage with the increasingly sophisticated technology of construction.

article.value: The imaginative use of wood, stone, and concrete and the overall impression of strength in Antonio’s Manila Polo Club, built in 1955, are persuasive indications of latter-day Filipinism. The circular Chapel (now Church) of the Holy Sacrifice of the UP, designed by Leandro Locsin and built in 1955, used thin-shell concrete construction.

Architectural Styles. The development of modern architecture in the Philippines, which had its beginnings with the introduction of art deco in the 1930s, entered a second phase after World War II, during the building boom of the reconstruction years, and during the emergence of a new generation of architects, a number of whom had been trained in the United States. Both Cesar Concio and Carlos Arguelles had earned master’s degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT); Angel Nakpil had a master’s degree from Harvard University, where he had been a disciple of Walter Gropius; and Alfredo Luz held a bachelor’s degree from the University of California at Berkeley. One prestigious architect of this period who had no foreign training was Gabriel Formoso.

The architecture of the 1950s was influenced by the International Style, which was characterized by asymmetric composition, bold rectangular forms, plain wall surfaces, clean lines, and large windows. The style was understood to be based also on the principle that form follows function. The style was to remain popular well into the 1960s.

A characteristic feature of many buildings of this time was the brise-soleil, also called sunbreak or sunbreaker, a reinforced-concrete screen composed of vertical and horizontal fins which protected windows and interiors from the glare and heat of direct sunlight. The invention of this device is attributed to the French-Swiss architect Le Corbusier (Charles Edouard Jeanneret). Its popularity in the Philippines could have resulted from its successful application in the Ministry of Education and Health Building in Rio de Janeiro, designed by the Brazilian architects Lucio Costa and Oscar Niemeyer with Le Corbusier as consultant, which was completed in 1942.  One of the first local buildings that used the brise-soleil was the Engineering and Architecture Building of the University of Santo Tomas (UST), designed by Julio Victor Rocha, then dean of the school of architecture.

With the use of reinforced concrete and structural steel, buildings could break out of the post-and-lintel pattern and employ more visually exciting features such as canopies over entrances, wide overhangs, spacious balconies, and stairways projecting daringly from walls of columns, appearing to float. Cantilevers, which create a sense of lightness, movement, and unimpeded space, would be used more frequently in the second phase of the development of modern architecture in the Philippines, and more stunningly in the succeeding phase.

Iconic Buildings and Filipinism. Rodrigo Perez (1994) speaks of a “romantic strain” that “appears in Filipino architecture of various traditions and periods.” What he meant was that Philippine architecture celebrates what is perceived and thought to be Filipino and this expresses itself in the infusion of ornament in a design.

The term romanticism is problematic because it is not an architectural style. The term “Filipinism” is more appropriate for describing conscious attempt to give buildings a distinct Filipino look. The government was complicit in fostering this trend. One of the designs submitted for the new capitol at Quezon City came from Federico S. Ilustre, the consulting architect of the Bureau of Public Works. He designed a central tower based on the Kalinga kalasag or shield as the centerpiece for a pastiche of designs from domes to what was said to be Malayan architecture. This 1958 design was not built; it received a scathing commentary from the League of Philippine Architects when an exhibit presenting the designs of the proposed new national capitol was mounted.

This did not stop the Public Works from pursuing the vision of a Filipino architectural design. Its Division of Architecture wrote earlier in 1957: “The architects and engineers in the Division of Architecture have collaborated and dedicated themselves to pursue an obsession in the search and creation of a distinguishing Filipino character in architecture as well as in the arts, born out of an emerging new culture blended with the touches and tone of the resurging past” (Lico 2008, 390).

During the pre-World War II era, Juan Arellano introduced Filipino motifs in his designs for city halls and government buildings in the Cordillera and Mindanao. Pursuing a direction initiated by his uncle Juan Arellano, Otilio Arellano sought inspiration in such motifs as the salakot, the mandala or haystack, and the panolong or Maranao protruding beam-end. Some of his contemporaries would later evoke the steep roofs, capiz windows, wooden panels, and stone walls of the bahay na bato (stone house). While the early modern buildings concealed the pitched roof and its gutters behind parapets to create the appearance of a flat roof, some later buildings would expose, if not dramatize, the pitched roof and thereby emphasize their tropical character. Examples are Sulo Hotel in Makati City and the first Max’s Restaurant in Quezon City.

In the main building of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), completed in 1969, Leandro Locsin brings principles and form derived from vernacular architecture although abstracted in the massive, cantilevered, visually floating block of the facade and the sculptured space of the main lobby. Formoso’s Asian Institute of Management (AIM) building is distinctively modern yet evocative of past styles. Built in 1970, with stonewalls and modern bandeja (traylike) panels, it evokes the bahay na bato.

Various currents converge and flow together in modern Filipino architecture: liberation from formalism; rediscovery of the native heritage; sense of history; sculptural approach to design; adventurousness and the willingness to experiment; focus on the symbolic and the expressive in architecture; the striving for warmth, vitality and richness, and commitment to the human being as the center of architecture.

In the 1950s, a strain of modern architecture was inspired by space age futurism. In 1959, Marcos de Guzman designed the residence of Artemio Reyes using the pateriform or the flying saucer shape. In the 1960s, the Mañosa Brothers designed the house of Ignacio Arroyo located on a cliff’s edge and overlooking Marikina in the same style. Its undulating roof and semi-circular balcony evoked an extraterrestrial vehicle. Also in the 1960s, Aida Cruz de Rosario designed a house in Baguio as an elevated octagon raised six meters above ground and lifted by arch support. Such shapes were popularly correlated to the home of Jetson’s, a popular Hanna-Barbera space age cartoon aired on television beginning in 1962. The saucer shape persisted to the 1970s in circular revolving restaurants and view decks of buildings in Manila, Pasig, and Cebu.
Forms

Dwellings and Residences. Despite the efforts of government and the private sector at ameliorating the dire need for adequate housing, the housing projects and the gated villages could only cater to the working and salaried class which could afford to pay the monthly amortization for these houses. By now, there were many in the cities who could not afford such homes. Displaced by World War II due to the destruction of their residence or lured by the prospects of work and the cultural and social amenities of the city, more and more of the population flocked to the urban centers from all regions of the country. With many of these migrants unable to find affordable and accessible housing, the phenomenon of shoddy informal dwellings housing the city’s poor grew. Their residents were derided and called “squatters” because they occupied land which they did not own.

These communities were characterized by makeshift houses called barong-barong or shanties. The barong-barong represents the architecture of poverty. Built on public land, idle land, or land owned by others, along railroad tracks or near garbage dumps, along esteros or on riverbanks, along seawalls or under bridges, they form settlements ranging from 10 or 30 households to several hundreds or thousands. They may have only one room or several rooms, and one or more floors. Their floor area ranges from six to 30 sqm. They are generally constructed of discarded or recycled materials: rusty iron sheets, plywood, cardboard, sawali thatch, plastic sheets, mats, canvas, and just about anything that can serve as a roof and sidings.

The floor may be raised a few steps above the ground, or it may be the ground itself, covered with plastic mats to protect the dwellers from dampness. The roof is usually of one slope. A larger structure may have a double-slope roof or a combination of one-slope roofs. It may have a window or two on only one side, if the house is too closely built to others, or windows on two or more sides, if the house is far enough from its neighbors.

Its sidings are patchwork of various materials. Posts, beams, rafters, and studs are put together hastily, whether with nails or lashing. Easily consumed by fire, knocked down by storms, washed away by floods, or demolished by eviction teams, the shanty just as easily rises from total collapse. Its fragile construction reveals both the native genius for improvisation and a certain fatalism.

Those who could pay to build or buy new homes would often opt for the bungalow. After World War II, this sprawling one-story house, inspired by the bungalows or ranch houses of California, became fashionable. A terrace, open or roofed, replaced the porch. Large picture windows, sliding doors, and French doors brought the outdoors in. Whereas the house of earlier years opened to a front yard, the house of the motorized age shielded itself against the street and opened to landscaped lawns at the back.

Later versions of this house had prominent roofs, recalling the bahay na bato, and wooden lattices similar to the frames of capiz windows, elegantly carved woodwork, and massive stone walls. With the rising cost of land and the reduced size of lots even in affluent areas, homeowners went back to building two-story houses.

The one-and-a-half-story house, which emerged after World War II, had one story on one side and two on the other. The one-story section was the living room and dining room; the second story section had bedrooms on the upper floor. The roof sloped down from the two-story section to the one-story section, giving the latter a high ceiling on its two-story side. Access to the bedrooms was through a balcony from which one could look down to the living room. One-and-a-half story houses did not always have this kind of roof; some types had separate roofs for the two-story and one-story sections.

The middle-class bungalow was far more modest than its upper-class counterpart. Instead of a fully enclosed garage, there was a carport which could function as a covered terrace. Depending on the size and shape of the lot, the house was compact in plan, or somewhat loose and open. The latter form was more conducive to cross ventilation.

Both the bungalow and the one and a half-story house, especially those that adhered too closely or even copied an American model would in the long run prove to be incompatible with the Philippine setting. Because the first floor omitted the one meter or so elevation of the older pre-World War II tsalet, the first floor which was raised only about a foot from the ground would flood during the rainy season and typhoons. The low pitch of the roof did not allow rain to fall quickly enough, causing rain to seep into the roof and enter the ceiling. Some houses omitted the space between roof and ceiling of the traditional house and opted for exposed beams with hardly a space between roof and ceiling. This made the interior warm, increasing the buildup of heat because of the widespread use of large windows covered with glass, an effective heat trap. The bungalow worked well if the house was surrounded by a generous garden planted with trees and shrubs that cut down the heat and light from the sun by serving as living sunbreaks. It also helped for it to be sited at an elevated place free from flooding.

Since some of the middle class enjoyed economic mobility, their houses would be remodeled or expanded whenever funds allowed. The facade would be improved and decorated, or a porch or rooms would be added, or in the case of one-story houses, a second floor would be built. The Filipino’s concept of a house is not that of something fixed and immutable, but of something that could be improved, enlarged, or completely altered.

In the postwar period, the government built low-cost housing projects, such as Projects 2, 3, and 4 in Quezon City, adapting various plans based on the bungalow. These housing units were one-story structures, which were either detached or joined to others in duplexes or row houses. Some were two stories. With low roofs, floors on ground level, and minimum space, the houses were unappealingly plain. The walls were of concrete hollow blocks and the roofs, of asbestos. Since asbestos did not transmit heat, ceilings were considered unnecessary. It was not well known then that asbestos sheds fibers that cause respiratory ailments.

Government Office Buildings. In the period immediately after World War II, many government buildings, such as the Legislative Building and the Post Office Building, were repaired or restored. These neoclassic buildings were rebuilt but with simplified plans because funds were inadequate. The freestanding columns that decorated the Legislative Building’s facade was not completely rebuilt, only those at the corner bays. The post office coffered ceiling was simplified. In the provinces, government buildings were repaired or restored, such as the Negros and Iloilo Capitols, which the Japanese occupied and which survived the war fairly intact but had to be repaired. The Baguio City Hall had to be rebuilt but no longer in the Tudor style of pre-World War II but in a neoclassic style. The challenge for the government to rebuild was enormous and its success was partial.

The end of World War II marked the liberation of government office buildings from traditionalism. In the 1950s, new government buildings, however, experimented with modernism. Floor plans broke away from the formalism of historicist design, and such features as plain walls, large windows, and exposed columns and beams were adopted from the International Style. Sunbreaks and concrete screens were employed.

Whereas in the past only the Bureau of Public Works architects designed the government buildings in the post-World War II period, private practitioners were engaged to undertake some major projects. The Social Security System (SSS) Building in Quezon City was designed by Juan Nakpil. The National Library on T. M. Kalaw was the work of a consortium of architects called Hexagon Associates, including Formoso, Angel Nakpil, and Felipe Mendoza. The Central Bank Buildings were designed by Formoso; the Development Bank in Makati and the Philippine National Bank on the Escolta were designed by Arguelles. The Batasang Pambansa Buildings in Quezon City were designed by Mendoza. The Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) Building at the reclamation area was designed by Jorge Ramos.

In the early decades of the 20th century, government office buildings were regarded as, among other things, symbols of authority. In the postwar years they aimed to be symbols of progress, of looking forward to the future. Embodying a certain freedom of design, they foreshadowed the increasing freedom and restlessness of a new age.

Schools. While some schools rehabilitated their pre-World War II buildings, like De La Salle, St Scholastica, and the UP in Manila, the post-World War II era saw the planning of schools with large campuses away from Manila to its outlying district or to the suburbs. In the pre-World War II days, schools like the UP, St Paul’s, Assumption, St Scholastica, De La Salle, and the Ateneo had Manila campuses, but their sizes were limited, about 3 to 5 ha on average. The UST’s Sampaloc campus at 10 ha was considered the largest in the era but it was dwarfed by the UP’s Diliman Campus which was more than 100 ha. The large campuses were developed in the manner of American universities, like Stanford and Cornell, where the school campus was designed as a village consisting of school, common areas for shops, stores and canteens, sports facilities used during and after school hours, and housing for students and for faculty. The analogy between the new Philippine campuses with Stanford and Cornell is apt because both these American campuses were located in the suburbs, just as the new campuses were rising in Quezon City, at that time Manila’s suburb.

After World War II, the Ateneo decided not to rebuild at Intramuros or at Padre Faura, in contrast to St Paul’s, Assumption, St Scholastica, and De La Salle which did. Instead, under Fr William Masterson, the rector of the school, a 135-hectare piece of property was acquired from the Tuason estate. The site chosen was a ridge overlooking Marikina Valley and at the boundary between Quezon City and Marikina. Working with Gines Rivera, who graduated with a degree in architecture and planning at MIT in Massachusettes, Masterson worked on a general plan for building, starting with the Ateneo Gym, which upon construction was used to house building materials that had to be transported all the way from Manila some 20 km west. The first buildings of Rivera for the College were in the International Style, inaugurated in 1951. Then followed the Grade School, 1954, and the High School, 1957. The plans for these two clusters of buildings took advantage of the generous amount of space available. Except for the chapels, the Grade School and High School buildings were one story and sprawled following the contour of the land. The one-story buildings were connected by wide covered corridors. The school surroundings were landscaped. The new campus was named Loyola Heights.

After World War II, UST added campus buildings to respond to the growing student population and interests in other subjects and discipline. More schools built branches in the suburbs of Manila, following the model of American campuses adapting popular and modernist trends for buildings, which were functional and straightforward.

Hospitals. The largest construction project within a few years after World War II was the Veterans Memorial Hospital (now Medical Center), a sprawling two-story building with the front pavilions branching out at oblique rather than right angles. The hospital presides over vast grounds which have been developed into a golf course. A box-like structure with slab overhangs over the windows and parapets concealing the pitched roofs indicate the influence of the International Style.

Built in the 1950s, the Children’s Memorial Hospital (now Fe del Mundo Medical Center), located on Banaue St, Quezon City and designed by Concio, departed from the conventional plan consisting of wings or pavilions. All rooms were in one curving multistory block at the left side of the entrance, while at the right, in a low and compact block, were an auditorium and various common facilities. While the building exemplifies freedom of form in modern design, its shape was dictated by practical considerations.

Designed by Luis Araneta, the original Manila Doctors Hospital on UN Ave, completed in 1956, was notable for introducing elegance into hospital design. The lobby was dominated by a curved stairway set against a large curved window. Rooms were liberated from antiseptic white walls and sported cheerful or soothing colors. The hospital was entirely air-conditioned, which made it a novelty then. Jutting out on the right of the entrance was a restaurant.

The Makati Medical Center (MMC), Araneta’s largest work, was built in 1965, and with its nine floors, was the tallest in its time. In a large rectangular block, the building was accented at one end by a cylindrical block housing operating rooms, the intensive care unit, the nursery, and private rooms. On the exterior are flat, horizontal strips that serve as sunshades. The MMC represents the high-rise trend in hospital design, which continued in such buildings as St Luke’s Medical Center on E. Rodriguez Ave in Quezon City, Medical Center Manila on Gen Luna St, and the annex of the PGH.
Commercial Buildings. With office buildings constructed away from the urban centers, sites could be more spacious and design would no longer be dictated by real estate considerations.

Since its introduction in the early 1950s, the brise-soleil has appeared in many variations. Vertical fins are set close together and the number of horizontal fins is minimized, as in Alfredo Luz’s World Health Organization Building on Taft Ave and United Nations Ave. In Alfredo Luz’s Ermita Center on Roxas Blvd, horizontal bands replace the horizontal fins as braces and thereby give the building stronger horizontal lines. In Concio’s Insular Life Building on Ayala Ave and Paseo de Roxas, narrow vertical fins are set close together within well-defined squares. In a number of sunbreaks, the horizontal fins are slanted to form giant louvers. For the Capitan Luis Gonzaga Building on Rizal Ave and Carriedo, Antonio designed double sunshades, i.e., concrete slab overhangs at both ceiling height and windowsill height for each floor, braced by staggered vertical fins of half-story height. The double sunshades are effective protection against both sunlight and rain.

Sunbreaks became necessary because wider and higher glass windows had become the fashion, courtesy of the International Style. On the other hand, they intimated that the Filipino architect was seriously concerned with solving the problem of tropical sunlight. Such concern was not always matched by results since faulty orientation often made the sunbreaks ineffective and nothing more than useless and costly ornaments.

The National Press Club (NPC) Building on Magallanes Drive, designed by Angel E. Nakpil, is one of the outstanding buildings of the period as it exemplifies the influence of the International Style on Philippine architecture after World War II. The NPC’s concrete and glass structure with its expanse of windows and its neat, straightforward structure give it an engaging transparency, a certain cheerfulness, and a virile leanness. There is nothing extraneous in the design. Since the building is on an east-west axis, it avails of maximum exposure to both north and south. That transparency becomes daring in the glass-sheathed cylindrical staircase and elevator shaft, the building’s distinctive and once controversial feature.

Likewise significant is Arguelles’s Philamlife Homes Office Building on UN Ave, a long rectangular seven-story block housing offices, with a one-story section housing a spacious lobby and a 780-seat auditorium, built in 1961. The building is a glass box in the International Style but with tropical adaptations. The gray-tinted, antiglare, heat-absorbing glass curtain wall enveloping the building is shielded from sun and rain by horizontal aluminum sun-baffles.

The pierced screen was the celebrated feature of the US Embassy Building in New Delhi, India, designed by the American Architect Edward D. Stone and completed in 1958. Not long after, the pierced screen was introduced in Manila and adopted as a kind of improvement over the brise-soleil. The device, which covers an entire side or several sides of a building, is a perforated wall which reduces and diffuses the natural light entering the building. Pierced screens were made of perforated concrete or ceramic blocks, precast concrete, or thick aluminum bars. The most notable pierced screen in Manila is that of the US Embassy Building on Roxas Blvd, designed by the American architect Alfred L. Aydelott and built in 1961.

The Magsaysay Memorial Building and the Ermita Center, both on Roxas Blvd, are basically office towers with lower buildings attached. The strong vertical component is balanced by a horizontal one that also serves to anchor it visually to the ground. The Meralco Building (also called Lopez Building) on Ortigas Ave in Pasig has a curved, concave facade, the consequence of a curved interior space so designed to avoid the train-like effect of long corridors. Behind the building, on a block of its own, is the Meralco Theater.

Central air-conditioning and artificial lighting have been major factors in the design of office buildings, and of other buildings as well. No longer is provision made for either natural ventilation or natural illumination, as in pre-World War II and early post-World War II buildings, since urban pollution rules out the former. Thus architects have been encouraged to design towering glass facades that are unembarrassed imitations of the slick-tech architecture of the US. Some office buildings are costly attempts at First-World architecture in a Third-World setting.

Stores, Superstores, and Malls. For maximum access, stores are traditionally located on ground level. In an urban setting, they usually occupy the ground floor of buildings that contain offices or apartments on their upper stories. Stores that sell a variety of goods are sometimes called bazaars. In the Philippines, stores that completely occupied multistory buildings developed in the early 20th century. Such stores, called department stores, sell a wide variety of merchandise including clothing, home appliances, furniture, dinnerware, cosmetics, jewelry, and toys. They are overseas offsprings of the American department store. Notable department stores were the COD department store in Cubao and the Good Earth Emporium in Manila.

While foodstuffs, such as fresh meat, fish, and vegetables, were sold in markets, imported items such as canned goods, fresh fruits, butter, cheese, and frozen meat were sold in groceries and cold stores prior to World War II. The post-World War II groceries expanded to what came to be called supermarkets, one of the earliest and largest of which is Unimart in Greenhills.

Rustan’s in Makati, which combined the department store and the supermarket in one building, initiated the superstore trend. Superstore buildings that followed include those of Shoemart (SM) and Landmark in Makati, Rustan’s in Cubao, Plaza Fair on Plaza Lacson in Manila, and Isetann in Manila and in Cubao.

In Makati, Quezon City, and Manila, stores were grouped in arcades and malls which developed from one-story clusters to multistory buildings. Shopping malls now contain not only shops and supermarkets, but also restaurants, amusement centers, movie houses, and complete department stores, and are adjoined by multilevel parking buildings.

Clubhouses. The Manila Polo Club in Makati, designed by Antonio, was completed in 1950 and set the style for future clubhouses. The abundant space, the openness to the outdoors, the soaring hip roof, rugged stonework, and hefty woodwork came together to symbolize the vigor, daring, and sense of liberation associated with sports.

The Valley Golf Club in Victoria Valley, Antipolo, Rizal, designed by Formoso, was completed in 1960. The floor plan combines a circle and a triangle, i.e., a golf ball resting on a tee. In the Club Filipino in Greenhills, built in 1970, Formoso underscores the Filipino character of the Club by simulating the bahay na bato. A hip roof, capiz windows, ventanillas, and stonewalls recall the Club’s first home on Calle Alix (now Legarda) in 1898.

Hotels. Within the decade after World War II the first-class hotels included the Manila Hotel, the Bay View Hotel, the Hotel Filipinas, the Shelborne Arms Hotel, and the former University Club Building, all of which were along Dewey Blvd.

The Manila Hotel at this time set the pattern for future hotels of its category. Aside from offering deluxe accommodations, the hotel had a variety of restaurants, a ballroom, function rooms, a bar and lounge, a shopping arcade, and recreational facilities such as a swimming pool and gym. The hotel had all the elements of a vacation resort, a convention center, a social center, and a tourist attraction.

With tourist traffic swelling to an unprecedented scale, more hotels were built not only along Manila Bay and in the Manila tourist belt, but also in Makati, and in such tourist venues as Baguio, Cebu, Iloilo, Legazpi, Davao, and Zamboanga. At present Metro Manila continues to have the most hotels.

The hotels along Roxas Blvd now include the Hotel Otani (formerly Shelborne); the Bay View Hotel; the Hotel Aurelio (formerly Filipinas Hotel); the Admiral Hotel (formerly Admiral Apartments); the Silahis International Hotel; the Holiday Inn; the Diamond Hotel; and the Hyatt Regency. On the reclamation area is the Westin Philippine Plaza Hotel (now Sofitel).

The major architects who designed hotels in the post-World War II period include Arguelles, Formoso, Locsin, Villarosa, and Juan Nakpil. The postwar hotels represent major developments in design, construction, and technology, particularly with respect to structural design, prefabrication, air-conditioning, and fire protection. Aside from the battery of engineers and technical consultants, interior designers and landscape architects have been the architect’s indispensable assistants in creating not only the landmarks but the pleasure domes of this age.

Churches. Immediately after the war, the reconstruction of churches, convents, religious houses, Church-run schools, orphanages, hospitals, and other institutions was a concern of the Catholic bishops in the Philippines. It would take decades to rebuild what war had destroyed.

A major project was the rebuilding of the Manila Cathedral from 1954 to 1958. Begun under Arch Rufino Santos, the project was placed under the supervision of the architect for the reconstruction, Fernando Ocampo Sr, who preserved the remaining neo-Romanesque facade and restored the church exterior in the same style. A new bell tower was built. He was assisted by a team of Filipino and Italian artists and artisans, including Galo B. Ocampo, who designed the stained glass windows in the idiom of modern Filipino painting, which Ocampo supported and promoted.

While the design team kept true to the original exterior of the cathedral, preserving as much as had survived the war, the interior, which had been gutted, was redesigned by the design team to allude to the past but not to slavishly copy it. The central aisle flanked by a colonnade was rebuilt but the interior spaces were planned and decorated in a manner that brought the cathedral up to modern standards.

Other dioceses also launched reconstruction projects to repair damaged churches and conventos. While some places like Bohol and southern Cebu were spared from damage, the churches of Cagayan Valley were all bombed in 1945. The churches of Panay were also damaged. At the end of World War II, these churches were shells with interiors gutted, wooden retablos burnt, and all nave and sanctuary furnishing damaged. With great effort, churches like Capiz (Roxas City) were reconstructed. Miag-ao’s interior was still provisional until 1993 when its church was inscribed in the World Heritage List.

Many churches that once marked Intramuros were rebuilt outside Intramuros after the war. The 1890s Lourdes Church in Intramuros was rebuilt by the Capuchins, with a new facade and a neo-romanesque interior, in Quezon City.

Two pioneers in modernist church architecture were the Chapel of St Joseph the Worker in Victorias, Negros Occidental and the Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice in UP Diliman. After its completion in 1949, the Chapel of St Joseph was featured in Life Magazine and called the first modern church in the Philippines. The chapel was designed by an American firm, Raymond and Rado. Antonio Raymond was a disciple of Frank Lloyd Wright. At the sanctuary was an apocalyptic mural by Alfonso Ossorio, depicting the Blessed Trinity and the Last Judgment. On the facade and in the baptistry were glass mosaic murals by Ade de Bethune. The wooden images of Christ, Mary, and Joseph were the work of a local artist, Benjamin Valenciano.

Locsin’s dome-shaped Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice, 1955, adopted the central plan to bring the congregation closer to the altar. The 24-centimeter-thick concrete dome rests on a ring beam, which is supported by 32 columns that follow the curvature of the dome. Wide openings on all sides make the interior accessible from any direction. On the walls between the openings are the Stations of the Cross painted by Vicente Manansala. Adorning the floor of the aisles is the River of Life by Arturo Luz. The crucifix, with the crucified Christ on one side and the Risen Christ on the other, is the work of Napoleon Abueva. Crowning the dome is a round skylight pierced by a triangular space-frame whose upper, outer section is a bell tower. From the pointed inner end hangs the Abueva crucifix.

From Intramuros, Santo Domingo Church was relocated to Quezon City and was completed in 1954. It was designed by Jose Zaragoza in a style he called “Spanish moderne,” a modernized mission style on a gigantic scale. The murals at the crossing tower were painted by Carlos “Botong” Francisco. These depict events in the life of St Dominic. Antonio Garcia Llamas painted the four evangelists, and Galo B. Ocampo designed the stained glass windows.

The church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Baclaran, designed by Concio and built in the 1950s, had a modern facade that echoed Romanesque design with its repetitive rhythm of Roman arches and a ceiling that evoked the ribbed vaulting of Gothic architecture, although it used a semicircular arch rather than the pointed or lancet Gothic arch. Large doors on both sides of the building were conducive to cross ventilation and turned the outdoors into an extension of the church for the overflow congregation.

The Christ the King Seminary Chapel on E. Rodriguez Ave, Quezon City was built in 1959. The floor plan was fan-shaped with an apse. Behind the altar table was a large stained glass window. Tall, narrow windows lighted the interior. On both sides of the choir loft were two tiers of balconies. Designed in Germany for the SVD Fathers, the facade had an expressionist monumental statue of Jesus at the last judgment and angels blowing horns to awaken the dead. Wrought iron rather than stone spires served as decorative finials.

Another notable church designed by Locsin was the Church of St Andrew in Bel-Air Village, Makati, which was completed in 1968. The basic structure is fittingly the X-shaped cross of St Andrew, from which emanates a billowing roof and a butterfly-shaped floor plan. The roof rested on deep arches, which are the entrances to the church. The baptismal font located at the entrance signified that one entered the Church through the sacrament of baptism. Inside and out, the church exemplified architecture as sculpture.

In the 20th century, churches of the Spanish colonial period were in many instances kept as they were, with at most minor repairs. Some churches that were damaged during World War II, on the other hand, were mindlessly restored and renovated. The entire nave would be demolished and replaced with a new structure or, if the old structure was preserved, windows were enlarged by chopping off sections of the old walls.

The impetus for this heavy-handed renovation was the need to find quick solutions to making historic churches useful. But there was another impetus. In 1965, the Second Vatican Council was concluded in Rome. The council had set the Catholic Church on a path of reform and an influential reform was that of the renewal of the Church’s rites or liturgy. Wanting to make the liturgy more accessible, the rites were translated into the vernacular languages. The biggest change happened in the celebration of the Mass. Where before the priest faced the retablo, in the reform the priest faced the people and entered into a common worship with them marked by a ritualized dialogue between priest and people. Although the full impact of the liturgical reforms did not happen until the 1970s when the reformed Mass text, popularly known as the Missal of Paul VI, was promulgated, liturgical reform began shortly after the council. Some priests had existing altar rails demolished to break the barrier between priest and people and had statues removed from the churches. Vatican II reform did not call for a wholesale restructuring of worship space; in fact, it called for the preservation of historic structures. But an iconoclastic streak infected priests, especially newly ordained ones and those who had studied abroad. They began remodeling historic churches, leading to a loss of church art and artifacts that fed a very active antiques market. Since the post World War II days, there had been an increasing interest in ecclesiastical antique objects. From the 1950s onwards, many of the old churches lost their statues, retablo, altar frontal, sanctuary lamps, and silver ornaments to art collectors and antique dealers. With a growing interest in sacred art, church robberies had become common.

The reaction to such cultural losses came late, as well as the awareness of the need for better researched and historically founded restoration. Thus, restoration efforts have had varying results. The Las Piñas Church, famous for its bamboo organ, counts among the very few examples of proper restoration. In many old churches, the plaster finish was scraped off to expose the brick or adobe walls. This resulted in exposing the material to the elements and to possible deterioration. Water seeping into the walls could eventually damage them. Seeds that get embedded in crevices and joints grow into shrubs whose roots could dislodge stones and bricks from their stable alignment. Equally disastrous has been the application of cement to smoothen the soft lime plastering of the colonial church. This layer is an effective barrier against moisture but while it keeps out the damp from rainfall, it cannot prevent moisture from seeping from the ground to the stones. Without a way for moisture to evaporate because of the cement skin, it condenses and causes the stones to deteriorate.

With few exceptions, Catholic church architecture in the Philippines in the 20th century, especially in the post World War II period, has consisted of serviceable, conventional buildings, some aspiring for originality, and some obviously lacking in inspiration.

The Protestant churches had their own path of development. Protestant missionaries began to evangelize in the Philippines in 1898 and soon after started to build churches. Like the first Catholic churches in the Philippines, the earliest Protestant churches were of nipa, bamboo, and wood. Later buildings were made of reinforced concrete. The Gothic-revival style and motifs appeared in both small and large churches. Doors and windows took the form of lancet arches. In larger churches rose windows adorned the facades.

The Ellinwood Malate Church, built in 1932, is one of the older buildings in the neo-Gothic style. The Central United Methodist Church on T. M. Kalaw, founded in 1899, built its first chapel in 1901. The present church, built in 1949, has a large recessed Gothic window in its gabled facade and is a restoration of the pre-World War II church designed by Juan Arellano. Other Protestant churches in the neo-Gothic style are the Knox Memorial Church on Rizal Ave, and the United Church of Manila on Recto St.

The neo-Gothic style, the architecture of the Romantic period, developed in Europe in the 18th and 19th centuries, and continued to be employed in the Philippines in the early 20th. Since most Catholic churches in the Philippines were in revivalist styles derived from Graeco-Roman architecture, the neo-Gothic style became the identifying mark of Protestant churches. By midcentury the Protestant churches turned to new forms. For the Protestant church in UP, Diliman, Quezon City, Concio designed a saddle-shaped building with a parabolic roof. Windows are cut into the lower slopes of the roof.

The Cathedral of St Mary and St John of the Philippine Episcopal Church, located on E. Rodriguez Ave, Quezon City, was designed by American architect and missionary John Van Wie Bergamini, and was completed in 1960. The tower, which rises over the chancel or sanctuary, is capped by a four-tiered stepped pyramid. Over the glass jalousies on both sides of the nave are three horizontal rows of capiz windows on square frames. The interior design combines dignity with a tropical openness.

The Philippine Independent Church, popularly called “Aglipayan” after its founder Gregorio Aglipay, took over a number of Catholic churches during the Philippine Revolution, but was compelled by a US Supreme Court decision to return them. The Aglipayans built churches of bamboo, then later of wood. Since their rites were derived from the Catholic religion, their churches resembled the Catholic.

The Cathedral of the Holy Child, the National Cathedral of the Philippine Independent Church located on Taft Ave, Manila was designed by Arguelles and built in 1969. The building has a rectangular nave and a rectangular apse with an east window. The baptistry is at the entrance. Aside from the choir loft, there are side balconies. The exterior consists of an upper block with sloping trapezoidal walls, resting on a rectangular block. The sides of the upper block project beyond the walls of the lower block to form wide overhangs. On the roof, running above the central aisle, is a row of concrete vertical fins set apart from each other, probably intended as baffles for the skylight.

The Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) call their churches kapilya or sambahan. The earliest of these were made of wood. The first concrete INC church, located on Washington (now A. Maceda) St, Sampaloc, Manila, was designed by Rufino Antonio and completed in 1948. It incorporated Gothic arches and spires that later developed into the identifying marks of the INC churches.

Juan Nakpil designed the Bishop’s Palace and Chapel, located in San Juan, Rizal and completed in 1952. The kapilya in Cubao, Quezon City, designed by Carlos Santos-Viola and Alfredo Luz, then partners, was built in 1954. After Santos-Viola established his own firm, he was commissioned to design most of the larger kapilya. In 1971 the INC organized its Engineering and Construction Department (INCECD), which undertakes the design, construction, and maintenance of INC buildings.

The INC churches have been described as neo-Gothic. However, since neo-Gothic refers to a particular style closely imitating Gothic architecture or employing Gothic motifs, the term does not seem appropriate, for the INC churches are, in fact, in more of a modernized neo-Gothic style. The pointed arch, the triangular arch, towers and spires, and tracery on walls are the mark of the INC style. Other decorative motifs are rosettes and interlocking trapezoids. Sambahan of the 21st century have adapted lines, motifs and decorations from the baroque and Romanesque. More recent sambahan use less pointed arches.

The INC style may be considered as having traditional elements, since it is derived from Gothic motifs; contemporary, since it pursues the modernist approach of simplification; and distinctively Filipino, since nowhere else in the world is it encountered. The architectural style is symbolic of the religion which, while based on the Bible, departs from traditional doctrine and is rooted in Filipino values.

A program of extensive and simultaneous construction of meeting houses throughout the country has given the Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter-Day Saints extraordinary prominence in a relatively short time. The majestically modern Manila Mormon Temple at Greenmeadows, Quezon City, designed by Felipe Mendoza, has a steep roof and monumental spires. Meeting houses in various parts of the country, designed by Cresenciano de Castro, are characterized by gable roofs, plain walls, and an air of efficient simplicity.

Like other building types in the Philippines in the 20th century, churches have moved from revivalist design, such as the neoclassic and neo-Gothic, to modern and contemporary styles, whether functional or romantic.

Theaters and Cinemas. New movie houses were built after World War II, among them the Galaxy on Rizal Ave, designed by Antonio, as well as the Ever on Rizal Ave and Rizal Theater in Makati, both designed by Juan Nakpil and Sons. The Ever was unique for its asymmetrical lobby, the stairs on one side set against a wall-sized mirror. The Rizal Theater, now gone, stood on a lot of its own, and was not hemmed in by adjacent buildings, as was the case with urban cinemas. Instead of the balcony and loge being on a second floor above the orchestra, as in earlier cinemas, the three sections formed one grand ascending curve. The stage was large enough for concerts, musicals, and a memorable performance by the Royal Ballet of England.

Aside from the first-class movie houses, there were the second-run cinemas, which showed double programs and charged less for admission. These were housed in small buildings or in former first-class movie houses that had suffered poor management or poor maintenance.

In the 1960s, the Manila cinema district shifted from Rizal Ave and the Escolta to Azcarraga and Quezon Blvd. Most spectacular of the new cinemas was the Cinerama on the corner of the last two streets, which had the screen and projectors for the latest panoramic formats from Hollywood. With the urban sprawl, movie houses were built in Cubao, as well as in Makati, Greenhills, Caloocan, Pasay, Mandaluyong, Pasig, and Alabang.

The FEU Auditorium, designed by Antonio, was housed in the university’s Administration Building on Morayta (now Nicanor Reyes St). In the 1950s, it was the only and much used venue for concerts, operas, ballets, musicals, and plays. Manila’s first international film festival was held here. Aside from the usual sections—orchestra, loge, and balcony—it has a presidential box on loge level at the left of the proscenium.

The Philamlife Auditorium, designed by Arguelles and completed in 1961, is noted for its acoustics, and is still one of the best concert halls in the country. While its stage was not designed for theatrical performances, it has been used nonetheless for operas and musicals.

The Meralco Theater, an adjunct of the Meralco head office building in Pasig, is a tastefully designed auditorium that accommodates 1,080 persons. The orchestra, loge, and balcony are on one vast sloping floor. The stage is well equipped and more than sufficiently spacious for performances.

In 1969, the CCP Main Building, designed by Locsin, was inaugurated. This was a long- standing project where Pres Ferdinand Marcos took interest. As early as the beginning of his first term as president, he supported the project. In 1965, at the proclamation of Marcos as the standard bearer for the Nacionalista Party, his wife, Imelda, spoke of a dream to build a national theater. Toward the end of the first term of Ferdinand Marcos and two months away from the presidential election, the CCP was inaugurated. Attended by a host of celebrities, including California governor Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy, the inauguration was an extravaganza showcasing Philippine culture.

The center has two theaters: the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo (formerly the Main Theater), which seats 1,805, and the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino (formerly the Little Theater), which seats 402. The larger hall is a cubical structure, so formed for acoustical purposes. Seating sections include the orchestra, parterre boxes, two levels of side boxes, and two balconies. With its vast stage, excellent acoustics, sophisticated lighting system, and first-rate stage machinery, the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo is an incomparable venue for symphony concerts, operas, musicals, and ballets, while the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, is ideal for solo recitals, chamber music groups, and drama. The main building also houses offices, galleries, a library, and a storage area converted into experimental space for plays, called Tanghalang Huseng Batute. The building is an example of architecture as sculpture. A massive block protruding from the main mass of the structure appears to float over the entrance, which is on a podium reached by a driveway that curves around a reflecting pool with fountains.

The CCP would be emblematic of the Marcos regime’s use of architecture for statecraft during the era of martial law or the Fourth Republic. By the end of his first term, Marcos had built a reputation for improving infrastructure, constructing roads and bridges and widening and improving existing ones. During his term new superhighways linking Manila with the provinces north and south, called North Diversion and South Diversion respectively, were constructed. He accurately boasted that he had built more roads and bridges compared to all his predecessors. Marcos had gathered an able-bodied group of technocrats as his cabinet and pool of advisers. But he also strengthened the military by increasing its budget. Confident of his military backing and the accomplishments of his first term, Marcos ran for re-election in 1969. He was re-elected president by a wide margin.

End of an Era. Marcos’s second presidential term was marked by unrest and rallies, many participated in by students. Despite the long list of Marcos’s achievements and the completed infrastructure, problems like the growing number of urban settlers, inadequate public housing, poor education, and a sluggish economy dogged the Marcos presidency. Marcos was seen favoring a group of loyal businessmen, dubbed “Marcos cronies,” while focusing his ire on the traditional rich, the “oligarchs.”

After winning a second term during the Nov 1969 presidential election, Marcos went to Congress in Jan 1970 to deliver the State of the Nation address at the opening session of the bicameral legislature. Outside Congress, a large gathering of students from schools and universities in Manila met him at the doors of Congress. The students were demonstrating to bring to public attention various issues that despite Marcos’s achievements were not being met. Among the issues were the deteriorating economic conditions of the Filipinos and the problems facing education, especially its rising costs. The rally was covered by media and televised thus projecting the protest more widely. It turned violent as more militant groups influenced by the Communist Party, which were identified by the government as “leftist,” took the lead in the rally. As the afternoon wore on, the students dispersed but the more militant groups massed at the Mendiola gate of Malacañan. There the rallyists were dispersed violently.

This violent dispersal catalyzed even more vociferous and dramatic protests. This era was called the First Quarter Storm because many student-led rallies erupted in the months that followed. A high point of the student movement was the Diliman Commune, when in Feb 1971 students occupied the buildings of UP Diliman, set up teach-ins, and ran the university without the usual control of professors and the university officials. Riot police sent to disperse the students hesitated to enter the campus, so the military was called in. Threatened with fire power from the military and after many casualties, the students eventually dispersed. The government denounced the commune as communist-led.

Attention of the more moderate sectors in society turned to the Constitutional Convention, long a subject of discussion, as a tool for reform. To address the inadequacies of the 1935 Philippine Constitution, drafted while the Philippines was still a commonwealth under the US, various persons and sectors had floated the idea of constitutional reform. Marcos took the challenge and the campaign for delegates to the convention began, slated to open in Jun 1971. But no sooner was the convention assembled when accusations of interference in the election of candidates and the corruption of delegates flew forth. There was also fear that Marcos would use the convention to prolong his presidency, which was to end in 1973, following the term limits of the presidency set by the 1935 constitution.

In Aug 1971, in the progression toward the congressional election scheduled for November, the Liberal Party, the traditional opponent of the Nacionalista Party to which Marcos belonged, had organized a rally at Plaza Miranda, in front of the Quiapo church. Two grenades were lobbed at the stage injuring the Liberal Party leaders, the effective opposition to Marcos. The government blamed the Communists. At the November election, the Liberals won all the senatorial seats except for two which went to the Nacionalistas.

The following year, while the Constitutional Convention was still going on, a delegate exposed Marcos’s alleged bribery attempt and appealed for votes against a resolution banning Marcos from a third term and banning his relatives from running for the presidency. Then a series of incidents hit the news. Secretary of Defense Juan Ponce Enrile reported the interception of an arms shipment for the Communists. It was brought by the MV Caragatan, but the ship floundered during a storm at Palanan, Isabela, on the Pacific coast of Luzon.

A series of bombings in public areas occurred. This set the general population on edge. Then, on 22 Sep 1972, Secretary Enrile’s car was allegedly shot at. Although the car was riddled with bullets, Enrile escaped unhurt. Early morning on 23 Sep, Marcos announced over media that he had placed the Philippines under martial law and had signed the decree two days earlier on 21 Sep. No newspapers were printed and distributed that day, because Marcos had ordered the seizure and control of all media outlets like print, radio, and television. The Marcos presidency had not addressed the issues exposed by the many rallies and protest movement but his declaration of martial law, which included a strict curfew, ended all the rallies. Many more were silenced as Marcos rounded up political opponents and incarcerated them for national security reasons. The era of the Third Republic ended with the stroke of the presidential pen.
