article.value: Deriving inspiration from the ethnic tradition and vernacular architecture, Bagong Lipunan architecture merged modernism with tradition, in a search for primeval purity postulated as the true wellspring of national identity and the national soul. Thus, the elements from the vernacular and indigenous tradition were used. Schoolhouses of the Marcos era were especially being designed so that they integrated elements from the local area; thus the schemes for schoolhouses generated by Ministry of Public Works and Highway used the flaring beam derived from Mindanao’s okir for its designs of schools in Mindanao. Elsewhere, proposed school buildings used many elements from the bahay kubo, like its elevation from the ground, the steep roof, and the awning-type windows.

The hip roof, whether terminating in an inverted pyramid finial recalling the shape of an Ifugao dwelling or truncated as used in the Makiling National Arts Center or the Batasang Pambansa, was characteristically Bagong Lipunan. Lico (2003, 451) characterizes this era as one of “vernacular renaissance.” But vernacular architecture was not the only stream in Bagong Lipunan era architecture because modernism continued to develop. Modernism’s severe lines and uncluttered surface define the University of Life in Pasig. The sculptural use of concrete in PICC is modernist. Later, architecture turned toward an abstraction of classicism, when the Manila Film Center, 1982, was designed by Froilan Hong to evoke the Parthenon at Athens.
Forms

Dwellings and Residences. In the early 1960s, during the presidency of Marcos’s predecessor Diosdado Macapagal (1961-65), another form of mass housing, rather than detached residences, was attempted: namely, the tenement, a multistory, multiple-unit building, such as that along the South Superhighway, at Punta in Santa Ana, and in Tondo. This was not quite satisfactory. A perennial problem in the Macapagal tenement was that there was not enough pressure to bring water to the upper floors of the high buildings. As a result, sanitation and maintenance became a problem, setting the stage for decay. Occupation density also became a problem and criminality was rampant in this demoralizing setting. By 2011 these tenements had been declared unfit for habitation and ordered demolished but nothing has been done thus far and people still live in these substandard high-rises.

The multistory tenement was adopted with modifications by the Bagong Lipunan Sites and Services (BLISS) housing projects of the Marcos regime. It consisted of four-story buildings with two or four units per floor. These apartments were built in various places like Guadalupe in Makati, and Diliman near UP, and near Project 7 in Quezon City.

The BLISS apartments were better designed than the housing project units and tenement of the Macapagal era. With only four stories, the buildings had adequate water supply. By reducing the scale of mass housing and providing adequate open spaces, the BLISS apartments were an improvement but they were unfortunately too costly for the low-salaried worker.

Under Imelda, government had other projects of mass housing at Dagat-dagatan in Malabon and the Tondo foreshore for instance. In Taguig, it created Maharlika Village to house Muslims who had sought refuge in Metro Manila. Many had migrated because of the conflict in Mindanao. A mosque was built and also an Olympic-size swimming pool. The government recognized that the Muslims were good swimmers and hoped to generate future Olympians by encouraging them to take on the sports.

To decongest Manila, Imelda inaugurated a project of building satellite cities, which she made public in a speech on 7 Jun 1976 at an international conference held in Vancouver, Canada, the United Nations Conference on Human Settlements. There she announced the construction of Lungsod Silangan (Eastern City) on the foothills of the Sierra Madre in Antipolo. The satellite cities would be built along the Manila-Infanta highway that the government was building to link Manila to the Pacific Coast. The decision for the location of this city was arrived at through a computer-generated land use map, which respected the ecological balance of the area. The generation of this map was headed by DrCelso Roque. An area of 20,300 ha of prime agricultural land and forest was mapped out in Antipolo and in typical Imelda fashion, a pilot was built quickly and named Bagong Bayan (New Country), following the master plan of the Planning Resources Operations System (PROS) inaugurated in 1977. The model houses built were a contemporary adaptation of the bahay kubo. Raised from the ground by reinforced concrete stilts, the houses had steep roofs of galvanized iron sheets, a small balcony by the entrance, and steel casement windows. The houses were sited in separate family lots along a road system that followed the contour of the land. Some of the roads between the houses were intended for pedestrian traffic and were narrow cemented pathways. Beyond the pilot nothing much was done to concretize this scheme. The Manila-Infanta road came to a stop when construction hit areas where there was strong NPA presence and the road builders were harassed.

In the 1980s, mass housing developers promoted a new scheme that took into account the Filipino’s preference for a dwelling on ground level. A so-called starter house of 20 sqm was built on a 60-sqm lot. The house could be expanded to 40 sqm on ground level, and 20 sqm could be added further by constructing a second floor.

A new method of construction has been applied in a housing project in Vitas, Tondo, comprising 1,664 units distributed among 27 four-story buildings on a 2.5-hectare site. Prefabricated box-shaped concrete units are stacked in such a manner that 29 units and the spaces between them result in a total of 50 dwellings. The system, designed by Cesar Canchela, is called the Canchela Shelter Components and Stacking Process for Multi-story Buildings.

The high-rise dwelling resonated with the private sector. During this era, the multiple residence and multiple-owned condominium buildings arose. Developers would build the high-rises and sell the individual apartment units even before construction at a special pre-construction price, which could be cheaper by 30 percent or more than the selling price upon completion. It was an attractive investment for those who had money to spare or who were looking for residence in a more central location, close or within the business district of an area, rather than in the gated villages.

Makati is the birthplace of condominiums, where apartments were rented and where condominium units, which could be residential or office space, were bought. Some of the best apartment and condominium buildings stand in a row on Ayala Ave, like the Urdaneta Apartments designed by Arguelles, the Twin Towers by William Coscolluela, and the Ritz Towers by Sindiong.

Most townhouses are, curiously, located not in town but in the suburbs or in quiet residential areas. The spacious lots of old mansions in Quezon City and San Juan have been taken over by townhouses. A townhouse is the upper-class version of the row house. It is a two- or three-story substantially built unit that stands cheek by jowl with similar units. Townhouses are usually in guarded compounds and are arranged in a straight line or around courts. Common facilities in the compound include playgrounds and swimming pools.

Following the Filipinist slant of Bagong Lipunan architecture, architects who designed residences of the upper class adapted many features from vernacular and local traditions like the use of adobe, terra cotta tiles from Vigan, rough walls like the CCP’s, and Mactan stones, while employing modern concepts of residential design geared for safety, comfort, and convenience.

Government Office Buildings. Another aspect of the Bagong Lipunan architectural program was to preserve and reuse the legacy of the past. This expressed itself in the interest in heritage conservation. Intramuros and Malacañan were the centers of such conservation.

Imelda took a more active and decisive hand at restoring the walls of Intramuros. Previously, the cleaning and rehabilitation of the walls began under Macapagal, when informal residents living in the vaults of the wall or within the walled city were relocated to Sapang Palay and the unemployed given temporary work cleaning the walls and Intramuros under Macapagal’s Emergency Employment Agency (EEA). Under Imelda, the replastering of the walls, the reconstruction of its damaged gates, and the archaeological investigation of Intramuros began. In 1979, PD 1616 created the Intramuros Administration (IA) to take charge of Intramuros and oversee its conservation. IA was placed under the Ministry of Human Settlements, which Imelda headed.

Among the projects of IA was the reconstruction of the Palacio del Gobernador where the Human Settlements would have its office. The Palacio was damaged in the earthquakes of 1863 and 1880 and was left in ruins when the governor general transferred residence to Malacañan. The empty adobe shell of its first story became the base for a 14-story tower, which while evoking the lines of neoclassicism challenged the traditional zoning laws of Intramuros, which set restrictions for building heights. The tower rivaled the bell tower of the Manila Cathedral in height, falling a few meters below the tower’s cupola. While the Palacio del Gobernador’s tower respected the letter of the law that no structure in Intramuros should be taller than the cathedral tower, it decisively changed the landscape of the area around Plaza Mayor.

Malacañan, another historic building, fell into the process of restoration and renovation. Although Malacañan had been renovated, expanded, and adapted to new uses by its residents from American governors general to Philippine presidents, during the Marcos era, it took the lead in projecting Philippine architecture even more. In 1965, the Marcos Room was added to the residential section. The Executive Building erected in 1921 by Gov-Gen Leonard Wood had its second floor cleared to make way for the Maharlika Hall in 1975. This building housed the Office of the President.

From 1978 to 1979, Imelda had the presidential palace’s residential area renovated. Windows were covered with bulletproof glass, the external walls pushed forward and central air-conditioning was installed. At the east and residential wing, an open atrium from the time of Gov Dwight Davis was covered with a colored fiberglass skylight embellished with stylized coconut leaves in a sunburst design of eight rays. On the second floor of the atrium, bas-reliefs carved by Paete artisans interpreted the historic works of Angono artist Carlos “Botong” Francisco. The private quarters of the First Family were paneled with Philippine hardwood, given a coffered ceiling and decorated with carvings by Betis artisans. Spanish colonial furniture was mixed with pieces in other European and Asian styles.

Malacañan’s main wing, Kalayaan, housed the Rizal Hall or Ceremonial Hall, the place for grand meetings with large groups. Like the residential quarters the hall was paneled with hardwood and had two domed coffered ceilings reminiscent of the ceiling design of the Pantheon in Rome. In the center of the ceiling were hung wood and crystal chandeliers. Swags and other ornaments of carved wood decorated the entrances from which hung curtains. Capiz was used to filter light coming through the windows and capiz dividers were used to mark out space. On a raised platform with a carved background of hardwood made to resemble sawali or woven bamboo was the presidential seal. Underneath, the president would sit for important occasions. The floor was carpeted crimson with yellow gold trim designed as a braided rope and swags of foliage. All told in 1979, seven years after the declaration of martial law, Malacañan was awash with the elements of Bagong Lipunan nationalist aesthetics.

In 1978, the long-standing steel structure left derelict for decades was reused for the new legistature in Quezon City. The central session hall of the complex, designed by Felix Mendoza, had a truncated pyramid roof. Flanking it on two sides and connected by wide low corridors were the multistory office buildings of the new Batasang Pambansa.

In 1978, the Security Plant Complex of the Central Bank of the Philippines, was established in Quezon City. Surrounded by a dry moat and tall fence, this complex was responsible for refining and minting gold, minting coins, printing money and other security papers such as passports, Internal Revenue stamps, Treasury warrants, etc. Its building is in a severe bunker style modernist architecture. It conveys solidity, stability, and impregnability.

In 1981, the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) moved from Quezon City to a new office complex in Roxas Blvd’s reclamation area. Designed by Jorge Ramos, the complex is a modernist horizontal structure composed of clusters of buildings of various heights.

Schools. The amelioration of education was another project undertaken under martial law. University of Life in Pasig was to be a signature school that would combine the best of the university and the technical curriculum. Its buildings were decidedly more modernist but it nodded to the vernacular in its use of natural material like bricks and adobe.

A school unique for its setting and tropical architecture is the National Arts Center on the slopes of Mt Makiling in Laguna, and the adjoining high school for the arts. The buildings of the complex were designed by Locsin. Imelda dreamt of establishing a Parnassus of the arts, where young, talented, and promising artists were recruited from the graduates of the elementary years and transported to live in an atmosphere that breathed art, away from the corruption of the cities. The resident faculty was then limited in number. Many were administrators. Teachers from UP were bused in to teach or in some cases, the students were brought to Manila for classes.

Locsin departed from his abstraction of vernacular architecture and constructed the National Arts Center with the hip roof of vernacular architecture. He, however, cut off the apex, making the outline that of a truncated pyramid. The adjoining buildings were in a similar style. The idyllic setting amidst a tropical forest made Locsin take advantage of the outdoors; this is especially evident in the school’s open chapel.

The influence of Bagong Lipunan nativist aesthetics were echoed in private schools like the Asian Institute of Management building in Makati, a major work of Gabriel Formoso. It is an efficient, well-equipped building with wooden panels or bandejas and adobe stone on the exterior, a style alluding to the bahay na bato (stone house). Spacious carpeted, air-conditioned classrooms set apart the International School, designed by Jose Mañosa, who gave the buildings a nativisitic air by using brick facings that alluded to bricks used during the Spanish era. The Benedictine Abbey School (Saint Benedict College, later San Beda-Alabang) in Alabang, Muntinlupa, also by Mañosa, departed from the standard floor plan. Instead of rectangular rooms arranged in a row along a corridor, hexagonal classrooms were clustered around a central space, creating a sense of community like rural barrios and sitios where houses clustered around a focus, like a chapel or the house of the village leader. The school building also modified the hip roof of Philippine vernacular architecture to fit the hexagonal plan.

Hospitals. Imelda took an interest in hospitals. One project was the expansion of the Philippine General Hospital. Along with the rehabilitation of the pre-World War II buildings was the addition of a seven-story tower complex. Respecting the lines of the heritage building, architect Jorge Ramos echoed the arcades of the Mission revival style of Parsons. The completed project was inaugurated on 2 Jul 1985, Imelda’s birthday. Ramos had earlier worked with Imelda in building the Philippine Heart Center, which came about after Imelda had visited Houston and seen the specialized hospital dedicated to the circulatory system. Later, Imelda would push for other specialized hospitals along East Ave and the Quezon Circle in Quezon City.

The Philippine Heart Center for Asia in Quezon City, designed by Ramos and inaugurated on 14 Feb 1975, has two types of accommodations for patients: wards and private rooms. The latter are grouped into “petals,” i.e., 10 to 14 rooms are clustered around the nurses’ station and are accessible to visitors through peripheral corridors, which are continuous glassed-in balconies. This arrangement requires more space than the standard rows of rooms along corridors.

Just as the Bagong Lipunan fostered a return to roots through architecture, Imelda commissioned local artists to create nativist works, particularly large murals for various buildings celebrating Malakas and Maganda. The Philippine Heart Center mural portrayed Imelda Marcos as a loving mother in Filipina dress embracing the handicapped, aged, and infirm of all ages. Flanking her are troops of doctors, nurses, and health specialists.

The National Kidney Institute, also in Quezon City, was a two-story, Y-shaped building with a courtyard at the center, which was later roofed. Recently, the hospital was remodeled with additional wings obscuring the original plan.

The floor plan of the Lung Center of the Philippines is basically two “diamonds” or two squares in diagonal position, hanging by their top corners from the arms of a T and joined at their middle corners at the shafts of a T. A horizontal bar, running through the center of the diamonds, forms the “spine” where common facilities are located. The sides of the diamonds, called “wings,” contain the rooms and wards. Vertical bars running through the centers of the squares are supplementary corridors. In the T-block are common facilities. The bottom of the T, aligned with the bottom corners of the diamonds, form the entrance area. The “wings” of the building do not spread out, so to speak, but are folded and interconnected in a compact plan.

Imelda also spearheaded the construction of the Philippine Children’s Medical Center along Quezon Blvd and near the Quezon Circle. This hospital was especially dedicated to children with rare and terminal diseases like cancer. The center is in modernist style and established in 1980.

With rapid developments in medical science and technology, and with the specialized services and sophisticated facilities expected by clients and patients, the design of hospitals and medical centers has increasingly challenged the ingenuity and creativity of architects.

Commercial Buildings. The San Miguel Corporation (SMC) Head Office in Mandaluyong, designed by Jose Mañosa and completed in 1984, shines like a giant prism and recalls the Banaue rice terraces. Francisco Mañosa’s Tahanang Pilipino at the CCP complex and his tent-shaped Mary Immaculate Parish Church in Las Piñas are statements of the Filipinism he advocates, i.e., the return to indigenous architectural forms and the use of thatch, bamboo, and wood in contemporary buildings.

Locsin designed the Benguet Corporation Building in the Ortigas Business District in the 1980s and used generous amounts of stone facing, recalling the basalt formation of the Central Cordillera, the site of Benguet’s mines.

Malls and Arcades. The Milelong Arcade, whose facade was designed after the Milelong Barracks in Corregidor Island, the Creekside Arcade, and Sunvar Plaza in Makati are long narrow buildings with shops, restaurants, and offices in linear array on ground level and on the upper floors.

Greenbelt Mall and The QUAD in Makati and Ali Mall in Quezon City are large, sprawling multistory buildings housing a variety of establishments. In SM City in Quezon City, SM Megamall in Mandaluyong, SM Centerpoint in Santa Mesa, Robinsons Galleria in Ortigas, Shangri-la Plaza in Mandaluyong, and Gotesco Grand Central in Caloocan, the shopping mall is attached to a large department store, or vice versa. Shopping malls, such as Virra (now V) Mall and Shoppesville in Greenhills, Harrison Plaza in Manila, and various malls and arcades in Makati, are clusters of commercial establishments with no dominant superstore.

The mall or galleria is a long building with a high central concourse flanked by several levels of galleries on which various establishments are located. Levels are linked by stairs, escalators, and elevators. Where a long building is not possible, the concourse becomes a plaza or atrium, likewise several stories high. An outdoor feeling is created in the concourse or plaza with the use of skylights, fountains, and greenery. Banners, several stories in length, hang over the concourse, giving it a festive air. The ambiance is appealing to people for whom shopping is an act of celebration. The mall is not only a magnified market and a compact movie district, but also a covered promenade made especially inviting by central air-conditioning. A mall is a small city in itself housing shops, restaurants, supermarkets, department stores, movie houses, and recreational facilities.

Clubhouses. The Alabang Golf and Country Club, designed by Formoso and completed in 1978, contains its complex of indoor facilities in one vast rectangular structure. It represents the architect’s constant striving for simplicity in design. The massive roof, basically hipped but varied in height and configuration, harmonizes with the outline of distant mountains.

The Philippine Columbian Association clubhouse in Paco, Manila and the Makati Sports Club, both the work of Rogelio Villarosa, are sports complexes in an urban setting. While massive walls on the street side preserve privacy, wide covered porches leading to an open area provide companionable space.
Club Filipino in Greenhills, designed by Formoso and built in 1970, follows the style of the bahay na bato in its form and in its use of stone, wood, and capiz windows.

Hotels. Within the tourist belt, not far from Roxas Blvd, are the Manila Pavilion (formerly Manila Hilton), the Manila Midtown Hotel, and the Century Park Sheraton. In Makati are the Hotel Intercontinental Manila, the Hotel Nikko Manila Garden, the Manila Peninsula, the Mandarin Oriental, and the Shangri-la Manila. Near the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) is the Philippine Village Hotel, which has not been reconstructed since it was gutted by fire. In 1976, the Manila Hotel was renovated and expanded with the addition at the back of an 18-story tower containing guest rooms.

In preparation for the IMF meeting in 1977, the government made 500 million pesos available through foreign loans to 14 hotels to prepare for the influx of foreign guests. The Admiral Hotel, Century Park Sheraton, Holiday Inn, Hotel Mirador, Manila Garden Hotel, Manila Hotel (renovation), Manila Mandarin, Manila Midtown Ramada, Manila Peninsula, Philippine Plaza on the reclamation area near CCP, Regent of Manila, Silahis International Hotel, El Grande, Pines Hotel, Makati Hotel, Mayon Imperial Hotel, Davao Insular, Mabuhay Hotel, Punta Baluarte, Ambassador Hotel, Sulu Hotel, and Philippine Village Hotel were among those who availed of state-guaranteed loans. Within a short period, the massive upgrading and building of five-star hotels sparked the building boom of the late 1970s.

But the tourist-oriented hotel project had a downside. To shield tourists from the many urban poor settlements, 60,000 were evicted from the city and sent to relocation sites in the provinces. When time to complete the relocation ran out, shanty communities along the highway and major roads were obscured with temporary whitewashed walls, oversized plant boxes, plantings of coconut and bananas, and grass that was even spray painted green to give the delegates a rustic image of urban Manila.

The IMF set the stage for tourism to become an important dollar-generating industry. The Bagong Lipunan encouraged the private sector to develop tourist areas. In 1972, PD 1 established the Department of Trade and Tourism; then in 1973, Pres Marcos created a new independent cabinet position, the Department of Tourism (DOT). Under the DOT were the Philippine Tourism Authority (PTA) and the Philippine Convention Bureau (PCB). The DOT became the Ministry of Tourism under the 1973 Constitution and reverted back to DOT in 1986 under Executive Order 120 and 120-A, signed by Pres Corazon Aquino. PTA was tasked with implementing policies and programs of DOT and developing, promoting, and supervising tourism projects. PTA established hostels and other forms of accommodations in potential tourist destinations that did not have sufficient infrastructure in the form of hotels and lodging houses. Among its projects were the Banaue Hotel, Youth Hostel, and Mount Data Hotel.

Churches. The martial law era was not a notable era for church building. Among the Catholics, the traditional central role of the church building was questioned by the younger clergy who perceived that the challenge of the time was to rethink and reconfigure what Church as community should be. During this era, it was quite common for priests to celebrate Mass at venues other than the church or chapel. Masses took place in homes, hospitals, funeral parlors, and out in the open in picket lines and rallies, especially after 1983. The focus during this era was a return to the people. The basic ecclesial community movement brought the center of worship to the peripheries. Young priests were generally not keen about construction, looking at interest in such projects as pre-Vatican II.

While there was a slowdown in church building, Catholic churches were built and those built during the Fourth Republic shared the vernacular aesthetics of Bagong Lipunan architecture. This was not in imitation of the prevalent style but rather arose from another impulse. The translation from Latin into the vernaculars of Church rites was in consonance with a theme of Vatican II to dialogue with culture. This dialogue was called “inculturation,” that is, the rooting of Christian doctrine and practice in cultures other than the dominant culture of the West. Experimenting with indigenous material, motifs, shapes, and colors, both designers and clerics sought to integrate Philippine cultural expression with Catholic faith. A visible pioneer in this path was Fr Ruben Villote. Assigned to Tipas, a barrio of Taguig, Rizal in 1969, four years after Vatican II, he built the parish not by building a church but organizing the church community. Tipas had an adobe Spanish era chapel but Tipas was a poor community of fisherfolk, farmers, and poultry raisers. Not having resources, Villote decorated the church with the ingenious bamboo creations of artisans of the community. Named Dambanang Kawayan, it was a pioneer in the use of local material and the adaptation of vernacular aesthetics to church design.

Rather than grand churches, the more common structures were chapels in subdivisions, gated communities, and in the settlements of urban poor. Although made of reinforced concrete and galvanized roof, the structures were small, had open sides, which could be grilled, a facade and sanctuary. Decorated with store-bought, mass-produced statuary and art work, these chapels did not always have the benefit of an architect or designer. Typical of these churches is San Nicolas de Tolentino built in 1975, in Congressional Subdivision, Quezon City. Its facade of bricks is nondescript. A cement cross is the only ornament.

When larger churches were built, they were designed to conform to Vatican II’s norm that architecture should foster active participation in Church Liturgy. Claret School’s Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, 1972, was designed by Locsin, who conceptualized it as a stylized salakot consisting of triangles that spiraled upwards terminating in a finial on which the cross is mounted. The triangles are crossed by horizontals evoking the shape of a terraced hill. The interior reflects the exterior with the triangles leading the eye upward. The interior, like the exterior, is finished in concrete. The interior is embellished with a wooden sculpture of the Risen Christ. The church plan was a fan, a shape that located the altar as the focal point and had excellent sight lines so that the liturgy was clearly visible from all parts of a church.

Don Bosco Church in Makati was built beside Don Bosco, a school established by the Salesian Fathers who set up a house in Makati in 1951. In 1976, Jaime Cardinal Sin, established a parish for the residents of Barangay Dulo and San Lorenzo Village in Makati. The parish was placed under the care of the Salesians. The following year, on 15 Aug 1977, the cardinal officiated at the laying of the corner stone and on 4 Mar 1978, the church was completed. The church was designed by Jose Ma. Zaragoza, known for his design of churches. Zaragoza would take inspiration from the anahaw leaf which dominates the sanctuary. From the anahaw design is projected a rib vault echoing the anahaw shape. The church is fan-shaped. Eduardo Castrillo, an alumnus of Don Bosco, made the bronze crucifix that dominates the sanctuary.

The National Shrine Our Lady of Fatima, 1977, in Valenzuela on Fatima Ave is also fan-shaped, with exaggerated steep overhangs over the windows terminating in a crown-like effect. Large expanses of glass fill the the facade windows. The fan-shaped plan gained popularity because it was believed to be best suited for Vatican II’s guidance on liturgies.

Established in 1976, the Sacred Heart Church in Makati was built of concrete. The church was expanded soon after when it was raised to the status of a National Shrine. The church works on a modern interpretation of the Roman arch used in the facade and bell tower. The exterior is crowned by a dome. The interior, after its expansion and renovation, follows the design of colonial churches with exposed beams, an arco toral, and a semi-circular sanctuary with a retablo dominated by a painting of the Sacred Heart. The interior is more baroque than modern.

Built in 1980, Our Lady of Miraculous Medal Shrine was planned as a Greek cross with its transept crossing curved rather than angled. From the four points of the cross rise spiraling curves that come together at the center to form a spire and cross. The roof is of poured reinforced concrete. It was designed by Zaragoza, the designer of Don Bosco.

Catholics were not the only ones who built churches; other religious groups did too. The Iglesia ni Cristo built churches; so did the Church of Latter Day Saints or Mormons. Unlike Catholics, both groups favored a standard style, based on the gothic. Lico (2008, 427) calls this style “stripped gothic,” a simplified gothic. The INC style allows a certain diversity within basic forms. The apparent uniformity of style could be understood to signify solidarity or a common single-mindedness. In fact, such uniformity heightens the visibility and ubiquity of a minority church. The Mormon Meeting House used spires and other elements like tall windows from gothic.
The Union Church of Manila, built 1975, located in Makati, has an elliptical sanctuary or assembly hall. The roof, a disk with a crown at the center, appears to be of folded-plate construction.

Theaters and Cinema. The stand-alone cinemas of the 1950s to the 1960s were replaced by smaller movie houses built inside a mall. An early version of this new type of movie house was in the QUAD, a mall in Makati which had four small cinemas, named, Q, U, A, and D.

The CCP dominated the field of the performing arts. Not only was it the official venue for state-sponsored performances, but it was also the theater of choice because of its state of the art equipment. But Imelda had her eyes on a much neglected iconic theater, the Metropolitan, built in the 1930s but damaged by war and abandoned. Restored in 1978, it was inaugurated with great fanfare. After the Fourth Republic, the Theater fell into disuse and was left derelict, but is currently being restored again.

For the International Film Festival, the Manila Film Center, 1982, was designed by Froilan Hong to evoke the Parthenon at Athens. But the construction was met with tragedy. While a floor was being poured, the weight of the wet cement caused the forms and scaffolding to collapse, burying workers underneath. Because of the desire to meet a deadline, it was alleged that construction continued and no serious attempt was made to rescue the injured workers.

Infrastructure. Continuing the infrastructure constructed from 1965 to 1972, Marcos expanded the government’s involvement in infrastructure. Addressing the need for irrigation and hydroelectric energy, the Philippine Congress approved in 1969 the construction of the Pantabangan Dam in Nueva Ecija, but the project would not begin until 1971 and continued up to 1977 during the martial law years. Although the Pantabangan Dam would have submerged a 300-year old town, opposition to the plan did not prosper because by 1972, when construction was in full swing, martial law had been declared. Some 1,300 residents were transferred to higher ground and with them the town.

Another dam project, the Chico River Dam, sponsored by a loan from the IMF, met with opposition from the Kalinga because it would flood ancestral land. Despite strong arm tactics that included military intervention, the Kalinga were able to rally support to oppose the project and in the 1980s, IMF withdrew its proffered loan and the project ended.

From 1984 to 1985, the Light Rail Transit (LRT) was launched to provide Metro Manila a light elevated rail system, that would run through Taft Ave from its southern terminal and depot along Airport Road, arriving at Baclaran for its first stop and running all the way to Monumento, after traveling through Rizal Ave. Its route traversed three cities: Pasay, Manila, and Caloocan. The light rail was sponsored by the Ministry of Human Settlements under Imelda as a means of mass transportation and a system of easing traffic along Manila’s main thoroughfare. The LRT provoked controversy but this could not find expression under the Marcos regime.

Another project that would arouse controversy but could not be criticized openly was the establishment of Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation (PAGCOR) in 1977. Because casinos promoted gambling, the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines saw this as objectionable but they would take time before launching public protests against gambling. The government justified the establishment of PAGCOR by saying that it brought revenue to the government, second only tothe Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR). PAGCOR operated because of its strict laws about gambling and because many of its casinos were operated in the context of a hotel, one of which was Hilton Manila. Later casinos would become part resort or entertainment complex, usually high-end. Like Las Vegas casinos, aside from gambling tables, the complex provided entertainment and restaurant services.

In 1973, Marcos and his wife inaugurated the San Juanico Bridge, which crosses the San Juanico Strait to connect the islands of Samar and Leyte. With its main span designed as an arch-shaped truss, the bridge measures 2.16 kms or 1.34 miles long, one of the longest bridges in the Philippines, second only to the Candaba Viaduct in Pampanga.

A project for electricity generation, the construction of Bataan Nuclear Power Plant was begun in 1976, but was never finished. Built in Morong, the plant was to provide electricity to the export processing zone in Bataan and the rest distributed throughout central Luzon. While the plant was being built, the Three Mile Island disaster in the US had indirectly put a halt to the project and generated a review of the construction, especially its safety. The safety report documented that the plant had 4,000 defects and that it was built on a geological fault. By 1984, $2.3 billion had been spent on the almost finished plant. During Corazon Aquino’s presidency, its construction was abandoned.
End of the Regime

Before the fateful days of Feb 1986 that led to the ouster of Ferdinand Marcos and his wife Imelda from power, Marcos’s Bagong Lipunan was already falling apart. The dramatic rise in infrastructure projects and the many building projects of Imelda and the private sector, made possible by government-backed foreign loans, were hurting the economy.

Some of these infrastructure projects were overpriced and the practice of bribery culled from the private sector who wanted to bid or invest in a project marred the regime’s signature infrastructure program. The overpriced, unused Bataan nuclear power plant was symbolic of the way the Marcos regime had misused public funds.

The economy was characterized by uneven growth and despite the glorious propaganda of Bagong Lipunan, the reality was quite different. Urban migrants were on the increase and shanty towns were expanding. The land reform program began by Marcos produced uneven results and did not enrich former tenants of rice farms. In fact, they sunk in deeper debt because to raise high-yield rice, they needed fertilizers. The farmers could not afford the input needed for rice production and the government was unable to set up an effective system of financing the emancipated tenants. The government built infrastructure projects that did not function well, if at all, and much money was being used to service the Philippines’s foreign debt.

The regime was hard put financing its expenses. Taxes, remittances from Filipinos who migrated as overseas contractual workers, especially to the Middle East, foreign grants and aid, and income from the rental of US military bases and PAGCOR were not enough. Government corporations were not yielding income and some became the milking cows of Marcos’s cronies. If Imelda was able to make what had come to be known as “Imeldific” projects, this was made possible because of foreign loans. As the government found it necessary to borrow in order to finance its building and infrastructure projects, the Philippines’s foreign loans had mushroomed toward the end of the Fourth Republic. All that the government could afford to pay was the interest rather than the loan principal itself. This set the government on a downward spin to economic collapse.

Lacking financial support, many Bagong Lipunan projects were never realized. The era that celebrated the vernacular and projected an image of a developing country with up-to-date, state-of-the-art architecture and facilities, proud to display what was Filipino, showed its true color—an impoverished nation able to survive and project development because it could make foreign loans.

Already weakened financially, a political challenge appeared on the horizon when former Sen Benigno Aquino, said to be the only politician who could challenge Marcos, returned to Manila on 21 Aug 1983. Aquino said he was going to talk to Marcos and map out a plan for Marcos to step down graciously and make room for an election. Traveling under a passport with the name Marcial Bonifacio, Aquino was escorted from his seat as soon as the airplane from Taiwan had landed. Flanked by guards, he was brought down the emergency exit of the landing tube to the tarmac—and there shot to death. This assassination caused massive protests and the boycott of the businesses of Marcos’s cronies, causing the economy to drop by 6.8% and leaving the Philippines bankrupt.

Various other events weakened Marcos’s hold on power. Although Marcos had appointed Chief Justice Enrique Fernando to head a commission to investigate the assassination in early 1984, the results were widely disbelieved. He appointed a new commission in October which concluded that a faction in the military had conspired to assassinate Aquino, but the conspiracy reportedly did not go any higher than low-ranking officers.
There was also widespread rumor that Marcos’s health was compromised and he was no longer fully capable of governing.

Marcos’s legitimacy as president was called into question by the growing protests that characterized the years 1983 to 1986. Emboldened by the apparent inability of the Marcos regime to contain the demonstrations, the protests got louder, more vociferous and frequent. Succumbing to both popular protests and pressure from the US, Marcos announced a snap election in 1985, one year short of the regular election. Batas Pambansa 883 legalized the election. In opposition to Marcos, Corazon C. Aquino, widow of Benigno, and Salvador Laurel ran as president and vice-president respectively.

The elections were held on 7 Feb 1986, and the Commission on Elections (COMELEC) declared Marcos president, as it was reported he garnered 10.8 million votes against Aquino’s 9.29 million. Reports of widespread cheating and manipulation of votes led to a dramatic moment as 29 COMELEC computer technicians walked out, alleging data tampering. Both sides claimed victory: 52% of votes had gone to Marcos, while the Aquino camp, supported by the findings of NAMFREL (National Movement for Free Elections), counted 53% in favor of Aquino. Condemning the elections were statements from the Catholic Hierarchy, which had been growing more critical of Marcos since 1983.

On 23 Feb, Marcos’s defense minister Juan Ponce Enrile and the Armed Forces of the Philippines Chief of Staff Gen Fidel V. Ramos broke away from the hated regime, holing up in Camp Aguinaldo and Camp Crame with their followers. To protect them from attack by Marcos forces, people from all walks of life came in droves to EDSA, blocking main entries to the two camps. Using nonviolence as their weapon, the people made a vigil in EDSA. On 25 Feb, Corazon C. Aquino took her oath of office as president of the Republic of the Philippines. On the night of the same day, Marcos and his family were flown out by US planes to exile in Hawaii, ending a 14-year regime that was marked by authoritarian rule, massive plunder of the economy, and utter disregard for the constitutional rights of Filipino citizens.
Related Content
Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III and René B. Javellana
