text:
Introduction

From 22-26 Feb 1986, the world was held mesmerized at the political events happening in the Philippines. On the evening of 22 Feb, Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile and Chief of Staff Gen Fidel Ramos declared that they were abandoning Pres Ferdinand Marcos and had called on the military loyal to the Republic to gather at the adjoining camps, Crame and Aguinaldo, along Epifanio de los Santos Ave (EDSA). At nine o’clock in the evening, Jaime Cardinal Sin, through Radio Veritas, urged civilians to go to EDSA and station themselves between the camps. Although the call seemed unwise and foolish, by Sunday morning the crowd had increased to the hundred thousands and, by noon of 23 Feb, Enrile crossed EDSA to consolidate his loyal troops with those of Ramos. The Veritas transmitter went dead—sabotaged, it was believed, by Marcos’s troops. But from an unknown source, known only as Radio Bandido, broadcasts supportive of the events happening at EDSA were aired nationwide. Gatherings and protests like EDSA were repeated in major cities like Cebu and Davao.

Marcos and Aquino each had their own presidential oath-takings—Aquino at the Club Filipino and Marcos at Malacañan—while the crowd at EDSA had swollen to hundreds of thousands. There were more military defections to Ramos and Enrile and, by the evening of 26 Feb, the tide of popular support had turned. Marcos and his family left Malacañan, airlifted and eventually ending at Clark Field, where the family and others who followed went to Hawaii in exile.

The euphoria of Marcos’s departure was soon replaced by the hard task of rebuilding. Aquino took steps to return to pre-martial law democracy. After appointing cabinet members, governors, and mayors to their positions, she set forth to create a Constitutional Commission which by 1987 had finished its task. Ratified by a plebiscite, the 1987 Philippine Constitution set the stage for reinstating elections and other institutions of Philippine democracy.

Aquino Presidency, 1986 – 92. The administration of Corazon C. Aquino saw the decline of Bagong Lipunan architecture. Many building projects created by Imelda went under scrutiny by the Presidential Commission on Good Government (PCGG). Some projects turned out not to have been paid for or had extensive loans from local agencies. The Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) took over the Metropolitan Theater, built with a loan from GSIS which had not been paid. Other projects, like Imelda’s resort in Olot, Fort Ilocandia, and the Marcos house in Batac, fell under government investigation. University of Life went into a decline. The Santo Niño Shrine in Tacloban was padlocked and remained unused until it was damaged by Typhoon Yolanda in Nov 2013. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the Makiling High School for the Arts continued to exist. Both had good management teams to see them through the transition to the Fifth Republic.

Aquino opted not to reside in Malacañan, choosing instead as presidential residence a guesthouse of the palace on Arlegui St, an art deco residence built before World War II. After repairing Malacañan, which was slightly damaged by the onslaught of people who entered the premises in the euphoria of People Power and after the palace furnishings had been properly inventoried, Aquino opened Malacañan as a museum that showed the opulence and decadence of the Marcos era. Under Aquino, the former San Miguel Brewery, acquired during the Marcos era, was refurbished to serve as the new Executive House. The 1921 Executive House was renamed Kalayaan Hall.

In 1987, Aquino established the Presidential Commission for Culture and the Arts (PCCA), predecessor of National Commission for Culture and the Arts, to oversee the art and culture field. In the CCP, a new team took over, reorganized the center to serve all the arts except architecture, and pursued the thrusts of Filipinization, democratization, and decentralization.

The Aquino presidency was plagued with many difficulties. The government was bankrupt. The national debt was increasing and the economy was in bad state. A series of brownouts signaled the problems left by the Marcos era. The Aquino presidency was beset by coup d’etat attempts by military factions which had supported her bid for presidency but were critical of the slow pace that she took to achieve the reform she had promised. Factions still loyal to Marcos, especially from his political bailiwick in the Ilocos, launched protests against Aquino.

Although it was not a good time for architecture, the regime managed to address the need for improving roads and building flyovers to ease traffic in and out of Manila and set the stage for future development by signing into law the creation of the Bases Conversion and Development Authority (BCDA). Republic Act (RA) 7227, BCDA, was signed on 13 Mar 1992, a few months before the next presidential election. Although RA 7227 was amended by RA 7917 in 1995 and by RA 9400 in 2007, the rationale for the act remained. BCDA was an instrument of government with corporate powers “mandated to transform former US military bases into alternative productive civilian use” (http://www.bcda.gov.ph/). BCDA contributed to the modernization of the Armed Forces of the Philippines and worked towered socio-economic development.

Ramos Presidency, 1992 – 98. The building boom came later, during the presidency of Fidel Ramos. Ramos, who succeeded Aquino, restored Malacañan to its former function by returning to Malacañan and using Marcos’s office. He repaired the palace, which had been damaged by typhoons.

But the strongest effect of the Ramos presidency was opening the Philippine economy to more foreign investments under the aegis of greater regional cooperation. Under Ramos, BCDA moved forward. The Americans, who had left their bases at Subic Bay and Clark Field after they were devastated by the eruption of Mt Pinatubo on 15 Jun 1991, left behind large tracts of land leased from the Philippines but which had expired. The Philippines did not renew the lease.

Subic and Clark were contiguous to each other and were damaged by heavy ash fall. The recreational Camp John Hay in Baguio was returned to the Philippines with the exit of the American military. Under Ramos, these former American bases were opened for developers who would sign contracts for 25 years to develop the place following terms set by law. The amendments to the law allowed the redevelopment of other military bases. Aside from Subic, Clark, and John Hay, BCDA covers the Bataan Technology Park, Poro Point, Fort Bonifacio, and Villamor Airbase. Because it was located in the area of Metro Manila (NCR), straddling Makati City and Taguig City, Fort Bonifacio (formerly McKinley), is the most visible area of development. The conversion of the bases and other government lands became the focus of the government’s development project.

Government derived income from the sale or rental of these large facilities to private investors, and with money from foreign investors, created virtually new cities made up of high rise buildings. High-rises of multiple use were the buildings of choice because of the rising value of real estate, especially of properties near or within the ambit of the metropolis. The government also launched a BOT (build-operate-transfer) scheme where an investor was allowed to develop public land and property for a set period like 25 years, enough time to recoup investment and make profit. Thenthe development would revert to the government.

During the Aquino presidency, a privatization program was initiated with the sale of 122 government-owned companies, bringing the Philippine government $2 billion. Under Ramos, privatization was expanded into infrastructure. To solve the recurring electrical shortages and resulting brownouts, Ramos moved to privatize the generation and distribution of electricity from 1992 to 1994. Seeing the success of this scheme, the next to be privatized was the Metropolitan Water and Sewerage System (MWSS), a government entity established before World War II. MWSS went into partnership with Manila Water and Maynilad in 1997 to upgrade and expand the distribution system of water in Metro Manila, Cavite, and Laguna.

Economic growth characterized the Ramos years and spurred confidence that the Philippines was now on the road to recovery. New developments and new buildings rose not only in Manila but also in the provinces. Development was undertaken by large real estate companies. In the lead was Ayala, which had a long history of real estate development. They were among the first to locate at Fort Bonifacio, which was adjacent to Forbes Park.

Other developers entered the market. SM created SM Development Corporation (SMDC). The Robinson’s group, Villar, Fil Estate, Millennium and many more realty and architectural development companies invested in the bases. Much of development was controlled by large corporations that could bring in foreign investors and had the means to market to foreign buyers, like Filipinos living abroad or to foreign companies that were looking for a base in Southeast Asia.

Under Ramos, a 17-hectare development in Bagumbayan or Libis, Quezon City was launched in 1997. This would be known as Eastwood City. Within the development is Cyberpark, an information technology (IT) center approved by the Philippine Economic Zone Authority (PEZA). An agency under the Department of Trade and Industry, PEZA was enacted under RA 7916, and signed into law by Ramos in 1995. PEZA is mandated to promote investment in export-oriented industry in the country and to assist investors. It facilitates the establishment of IT companies in business processing outsourcing (BPO) and in knowledge processing outsourcing. It also encourages the establishment of special economic zones of businesses in tourism, medical tourism, logistics and warehousing, and economic zone development and operation.

The biggest government-sponsored project was the construction of the Centennial Park in Clark Field, Pampanga, built during the Ramos presidency. Set to open in 1996 to commemorate the centennial of the Philippine Revolution, the park consisted of manmade islands and water features that combined elements of a museum with a theme park. The Centennial Park was a white elephant. It was not completed and very few went to the park.

The Philippines, through the able fiscal management of the Ramos regime, sailed through the Asian economic crisis of 1992, unlike neighboring parts of Southeast Asiawhere the economic bubble burst that sent most of the region in a downward spin.

Estrada Presidency, 1998 – 2001. The presidency was brief, a little more than two years, 30 Jun 1998 to 20 Jan 2001. Ramos’s successor Joseph Estrada decided to take residence at the Premier Guest House and improved it as a residence and office. The interior of Malacañan was refurbished.

The Estrada presidency was not able to hold on to the economic gains of the Ramos era. Riddled with charges of corruption and plunder and criticized for its informal style of governing, Estrada soon found himself the subject of an impeachment proceeding but resigned from office before the trial could conclude. He was ousted from power by People Power II when the impeachment court decided not to present vital evidence against Estrada and massive protests against Estrada gained momentum.

Despite its brevity, it was under Estrada’s administration that Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) 2 was completed and inaugurated. This project began during the Ramos presidency. But soon after the inauguration, Estrada was embroiled in controversy connected with this very project because he awarded the use of the new terminal to Philippine Airlines, whose majority stockholder, Lucio Tan, was said to be one of Estrada’s supporters. Although the law creating PEZA was signed by Ramos in 1997, it is to Estrada’s credit that the Philippines became a major player in the emerging business process outsourcing (BPO), popularly known as “call centers.” It was during his presidency that the Eastwood City became operational. It was the prototype of the cyber city that was to emerge at Fort Bonifacio and the provinces of the Visayas, like Iloilo, Bacolod, and Cebu, and of Mindanao, like Davao, and cities like Baguio.

Arroyo Presidency, 2001 – 10. Upon Estrada’s resignation, vice-president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo took office as president, as mandated by law.

With great effort and sound management, Arroyo was able to slow down the economic decline of the Estrada years. As in the Estrada years, government was not into architecture, although Arroyo renovated Malacañan, cleaning out the personal effects of the Marcos family and turning them over to the PCGG. She had a Presidential Briefing Room similar to the White House Situation Room built. She recovered historic furniture, restored Kalayaan Hall, and spruced up the garden.

Arroyo focused on projects that would spur economic growth, so her regime was known for increasing infrastructure, like improving roads, building new highways, and opening sea lanes by integrating roll on-roll off (RoRo) shipping through the improvement of ports and the construction of new ones. Arroyo left a master plan for infrastructure improvement, which included the rehabilitation and expansion of the railroad system, a task given to Vice-Pres Noli de Castro; the expansion of the North Luzon and South Luzon Expressways (NLEX and SLEX) connecting Metro Manila with the provinces; the construction of the Manila Bay highway, a project that was in the original Burnham plan for Manila; and the development of areas surrounding the NCR. Under her many infrastructure projects were launched, including the upgrade of NLEX and SLEX, the construction of NAIA III and similar airport projects in the Visayas and Mindanao, like the new airports at Santa Barbara, Iloilo and Silay City, Negros Occidental, Zamboanga City, and the Cagayan de Oro airport.

Under Arroyo, part of the military base fronting NAIA III was redeveloped as Resorts World, a complex consisting of a hotel, casino, stores, restaurants, movie houses, and theaters. It was inaugurated in 2009 and was the first of the casino resorts to be built.

Benigno Aquino III Presidency, 2010 - 16. The first two years of Benigno Aquino’s presidency was marked by a slowdown in government-sponsored projects. Working with a program of “Daang Matuwid,” a slogan addressing corruption, Aquino had the infrastructure programs of Arroyo scrutinized. This meant that very little was done during the first two years of his administration. NAIA III went under review. The rehabilitation of the northern track of a railroad system that was to connect Manila with the Ilocos was a dead project. The contract for the railroad was allegedly flawed and China which was to be a partner in developing the railroad was no longer with the project. Informal settlers began to slowly return to the land that had been cleared for the railroad’s right of way. The building and expansion of piers and harbors—part of Arroyo’s scheme to promote and develop roro shipping—was put on hold.

Only after this period of examination did the government continue with projects that had been in the works since Arroyo. Under Aquino, NAIA III, which had been embroiled in controversy with contractors, became partially operational by 2008, and fully operational in 2011. Projects like road development, which had been developed under Arroyo, continued.

In the cultural field, the Aquino administration invested heavily in the upgrading and expansion of the National Museum of the Philippines. With Aquino, the old Legislative Building, which housed the office of the Prime Minister called Executive House under Marcos, was turned over totally to the National Museum. Following a master plan drawn during the Ramos regime, the Legislative Building became the National Museum’s Museum of Fine Arts. The Department of Tourism building (in pre-World War II period, the Department of Agriculture building) was turned over to the National Museum to turn into a Museum of Natural History, to be completed in 2017. Other museum branches were repaired, upgraded, and built. The Batanes Museum was built in a former American military base on Batan Island. Convention centers, like that of Iloilo City, were also completed.

During the Aquino presidency, two integrated resort and casino complexes were opened in a 120-ha reclamation area of Manila Bay within the jurisdiction of Parañaque. Solaire opened in 2013 and City of Dreams in 2015. Both developments are within the Entertainment City of the Philippine Amusement Gaming Corporation (PAGCOR) which was designated as a special economic zone by PEZA under a presidential proclamation in 2009 by Pres Arroyo. Solaire started construction in Jun 2010. The first phase completed in 2013 was inaugurated with Pres Aquino in attendance. City of Dreams, which had a sister company in Macau, rests on a 6.2-hectare property; it opened in Feb 2015.

Globalization and Architectural Development. Globalization as a process of international integration arising from the interchange of world views, ideas, products, labor, capital and other resources has its antecedents in the 19th century when imperialist nations dominated and exploited Asia, Africa, and Latin America. Advances in transportation and communication facilitated this domination. With the revolutions for independence, the Western empires collapsed but the newly independent nations were integrated into a web of exchange— economic, social, and cultural. In the 20th century, globalization grew at an increasingly fast pace as advances in container ships, fast trains, jet liners, and the development of mobile phones and the internet built a more connected world. In 2000, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) defined four basic aspects of globalization: capital and investment movements, trade and transactions, migration, and knowledge dissemination.

Closely allied to globalization is transnationalism or transnationalization. In economic terms, it involves the organization of production, where various stages of production take place in various countries to cut cost and maximize productivity.

Green or sustainable architecture, while not representing a specific style, is a global movement that grew out of the rising concern about the environment and its degradation due to human activity. Its origins are in the energy crisis and environmental pollution in the United States in the 1960s and the 1970s. Rachel Carson’s Silent Spring, 1962, is considered as the first to articulate sustainable development with green architecture. With the spread of the environment movement from the United States to the rest of the world grew the movement of “green architecture,” which sought to mitigate the effects of architecture on the environment. The move was to reduce the use of energy in the construction, maintenance, and use of the building. Also of concern were how materials were used, how they were extracted, how much energy was used to make them or what their “carbon footprint” was, and whether the materials used—whether natural or composite made in factories—had an adverse effect on the environment.

These initiatives of green architecture were preventive or curative but a more active phase of green architecture looked into the generation of power through alternative means like solar energy, the increase of green spaces through lighted interiors that allowed the cultivation of plants known to purify the air, and by rooftop and vertical gardens. A local green architecture evaluation and certification group is Berde. An international certification group is LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environment Design). Both are actively working to evaluate buildings and rate them. LEED uses a standard symbolized by precious metals, platinum being the highest rating given.

Philippine Response to International Trends. Much of the architectural development at this time fell to the private business sector. In general, since the Ramos administration, government has left business to take care of itself concentrating its interventions indirectly, through tax cuts and investments initiatives.

With the development of digital technology and other means of communication, the Filipinos’ proficiency in English and their ability to mimic various English accents, the Philippines took the lead in the international market in offering BPO services. This spurred the growth of the Ortigas Business Center and Libis in the boundaries of Quezon City and Manila. C5, the fifth of Metro Manila’s circumferential road, linked Libis, Ortigas, The Fort and the international airport, and became a corridor of development and high-rises. Some high-rises were offices, many for call centers, others residences, and still others for mixed use with parking at the basement or above ground, retail outlets, restaurants and convenience stores at the ground, office spaces in the lower stories, and residences at the upper stories. A common configuration was to limit retail spaces and offices to a podium, whose roof was landscaped as a garden, and to build a residential tower above the podium.

Because the Philippines was opening to a global market, the construction of an “iconic building,” designed by a world-renowned architect to attract international investors became attractive. Iconic refers to a building which is unique in design and has the stamp of its creator, an internationally known and admired architect. Although Michael Graves had antedated him in a project at Binondo, American Chinese architect I. M. Pei’s Essensa Towers, a residential high-rise for the high-end market at Fort Bonifacio was seen as a first in a series of iconic buildings.

Clients or developers justified hiring foreign consultants or architects on the grounds that the needed expertise for design and construction was not locally available. A local firm would form a partnership with a foreign company and in this way internationally known architects and firms entered the Philippines. Such firms and their projects include Michael Graves, World Trade Exchange, 1996, in Binondo; I. M. Pei (Pei, Cobb, Freed & Partners), Essensa Towers, 2001; KPF (Kohn, Pendersen, and Fox), LKG Tower, 1998; and SOM (Skidmore, Owings and Merril), Yuchengco Towers, 2001. Other foreign firms that partnered with Filipinos are HOK (Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum), Gensler, NBBJ, RTLK, and Arquitectura (Lico 2008, 510).

Globalization also meant that the new buildings had to be up to international standards. To ensure that quality, the Ayala Corp. had its own core of engineers and contractors, and soon other companies like SM and Villar had their own. These companies either had in-house teams of architects, engineers, landscape designers, and interior designers or worked with a set team. It had its own workforce of licensed plumbers, electricians, carpenters, painters, and a host of manual laborers.

Styles and Postmodernism. While the Philippines was going through political upheavals in the 1970s, there was a different upheaval in architecture. Although its conceptual origins can be traced to the late 1950s and 1960s, when its early pioneer, Robert Venturi, reintroduced the split gable in the Vanna Venturi house in 1964 and wrote a critique of modern architecture, postmodernism did not become a movement until the 1970s when postmodernist architecture came to prominence.

Postmodernism is the term used to define a worldview that has turned away from modernism’s accent on rationality, professionalization, industrialization, urbanization, secularization, order, and hierarchy in the newly formed nation-state, capitalism,and the market economy. Belief in constant change that leads to progress was a key element in the modern mindset. This was the guiding philosophy of Europe before World War II, buoyed by spectacular growth brought about by science and technology. But philosophers critiqued the possibility of absolute and total knowledge, and the claims of positivist science and philosophies like Marxism, which saw the inexorable progress from capitalism to socialism to communism. World War II and the detonation of the atomic bomb at Hiroshima and Nagasaki shook the world’s confidence in inevitable progress. The era after World War II culminating in the 1980s is seen as the last phase of modernism.

Postmodernism in architecture or postmodernist architecture does not represent one style—it is rather a perspective on architecture that has embraced a host of styles. Postmodernist architects regarded modern architecture as lacking in soul and imagination and unable to achieve the Utopia it promised. Working from Le Corbusier’s concept of a building as a machine for living, its attempted harmony of form and function, and the dismissal of ornament, the modernist strain produced boxy edifices which looked like clones of each other. The postmodernist wanted to return wit and ornament and to return architecture to its roots by referencing historical architecture. One of its vocal theoreticians, Venturi, coined the saying “less is a bore” in response to modernist Ludwig Mies van der Rohe “less is more.” Early examples of postmodernism are Michael Graves’ Portland Bldg and Philip Johnson’s Sony Bldg (formerly AT&T) in New York. Instead of the flat roof of modernism, it used a broken pediment derived from classicism. It also adapted furniture during the Renaissance and Baroque periods.

An early example of postmodernism in the Philippines is Gabriel Formoso’s Pacific Star Building, in Makati, completed in 1990. While distinctively modern, Pacific Star evokes the past by paying homage to the Roman arch, and does so with refinement and grace. Other postmodern buildings are Rogelio Villarosa’s King’s Court, 1990, Tektite Tower, 1995, and Renaissance Tower, 1995; Felino Palafox’s Nueva Ecija Capitol at Palayan City, 2003; and Dewey Santos and Felix Ngo’s designs for Metrobank branches (beginning in the late 1990s), where no two branches are alike. Ritcheto Alcordo’s Waterfront Hotel in Lahug Cebu, 1998, has turrets making it resemble a cartoon-like fairy tale castle. Sanctuarium, 2006, the largest columbarium in the Philippines, has a temple facade surmounted by a translucent dome.

Postmodernism had its impact on residential styles. Following the eclecticism of postmodern architectures, new developments, especially in vacation areas like Tagaytay, followed a theme development plan, landscaping, and architecture. Designs could derive from the Swiss chalet, the Greek residences of Santorini, Mediterranean, or Mexican houses, especially in its palette of contrasting, vibrant colors. There was a market for such styles as Filipinos traveled for leisure or as overseas workers.

A popular style of residential architecture has been described as “Zen.” These are modernist and postmodernist structures characterized by straight lines and restrained color schemes, usually earth-brown, black, white, and gray. Zen architecture modernizes many of the elements of the traditional Philippine house with its expanses of large windows, overhangs, and an interaction between the outdoors and indoors.

Postmodernism has been criticized, especially by the modernist, as being eclectic, filled with useless ornaments, and elements that have no function, therefore a needless expense and waste. It has also been described as stick-on-style: that is, a modernist building may be clad with precast ornaments or faux stones that quote some historical style. What began as an avant-garde movement has unfortunately been appropriated in designs that “seldom had the finesse and beauty of the original for they were reduced to an eclectic visual feast processed in the name of populism and consumerism,” writes Lico.

Although the qualities of good architecture are undermined in poorly planned projects, the postmodern creative spirit has shaped the Philippine architecture of the 1990s and the first two decades of the 21st century.

 

Forms

Dwellings and Residences. High-rise condominiums and gated communities are characteristic of the Fifth Republic era. High-rise condominiums were already built during the Fourth Republic and gated subdivisions emerged during the post-World War II era. What characterizes the Fifth Republic condominiums are their height and proliferation, and the gated communities, their more comprehensive planning and proliferation as new “villages” were built farther away from Metro Manila’s center. Quezon City, Valenzuela City, Laguna, and Cavite were all sites of development. In the provinces, Cebu’s development sprawled south to Talisay and north to Liloan. Iloilo’s development moved north toward Pavia. Cagayan de Oro’s development spread across the highway that linked Cagayan with Iligan and Gingoog. Davao’s sprawl moved north following the Pan-Philippine Highway, through Matina, Lanang, and the direction of the Davao International Airport, and toward Talomo and Dumoy. Baguio also opened new developments in Asin for instance and large tracks of land like Camp John Hay and Brent School have been the centers of development.

While the gated community concept remains essentially the same as it was in the 1960s, namely, a self-contained community secured by walls and gates, what distinguished the new developments were: first, they were developed following an economic scale from low-end to high-end; and second, unlike in the 1960s, where house lots were sold, many developments followed the Philamlife model where pre-existing houses were built and priced accordingly.

Mass Housing. The government continued to face the problem of growing population and the need for mass housing. While government continued with projects to build low-cost housing during the Fifth Republic era, private groups became active in upgrading and building low-cost housing. The Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) initiated housing projects for its members, for instance, in Rodriguez (formerly Montalban), Rizal. Habitat for Humanity has been active in housing. Gawad Kalinga, a local organization, has also been working with mass housing. Entering a shanty village, Gawad Kalinga first organizes the people, especially the men who are invited to help in building better houses, through “sweat equity,” that is offering free labor in exchange for better houses. Houses are sponsored by donors like schools and companies, and individual donors. The building blocks of the houses like beams and hollow blocks are prepared in the area with the cooperation of the residents. Gawad Kalinga houses are known for their colorful exteriors and for the common facilities, like a hall for meetings and for communal work. Gawad Kalinga has also launched a livelihood program to help in the upkeep of the residences built and help uplift the poor communities.

Government Office Buildings. With the devolution of governance to the local government, the national government has not built much. When the Senate was convened in accordance with the 1987 constitution that reinstated the bicameral legislature, the lower house went to the Batasang Pambansa and the upper house eventually to the GSIS building in the reclamation area along Manila Bay. The old Legislative building was turned over to the National Museum, as well as the nearby buildings known in the pre-World War II era as Agriculture and Finance.

The local government was more active in building. New city halls were built, in places like Urdaneta, Pangasinan, and the old city hall was converted to other uses like museums. Felino Palafox Jr’s design for the Nueva Ecija Capitol at Palayan City works with a severe interpretation of classicism with its arched windows and pillars. William Coscolluela designed the new Iloilo Capitol in harmony with the neoclassical heritage Capitol near it.

Schools. Private schools were in the forefront of developing new campuses outside the metropolis. San Juan de Letran, Brent School, Xavier School, Miriam (formerly Maryknoll), and Lyceum are some of the schools that have opened or are opening satellite campuses near or within new developments like Nuvali along the Santa Rosa-Tagaytay road. New schools like STI, AMA, Adventist, and others have also opened countryside campuses.

 

The trend is not limited to Metro Manila as provincial schools seek larger campuses, like Sacred Heart School in Cebu, which moved from its crowded midtown Cebu campus to Mandaue and Xavier University in Cagayan de Oro, which developed a new campus plus housing in the uplands of Cagayan in the direction of the former Lumbia Airport.

These countryside campuses, like Lyceum at Laguna, Batangas, and Cavite, offer the advantage of a wide campus opened to the countryside. Formerly Lyceum Institute of Technology, Lyceum Batangas was incorporated on 18 Jan 2000. Encompassing five colleges and an international school, Lyceum Cavite Campus in General Trias, established in 2008, is dubbed as the “first and only resort campus” in the Philippines because it integrates landscaping with the campus design. Gardens and pools are integral to the complex. The complex’s design is derived from the laurel leaf, a reference to the Laurel family who established the Lyceum chain. The leaf design is expressed in a canopy of curving roofs that serve as a shield against sun and rain for the buildings underneath. This canopy is supported by a steel structure independent of the building. In spirit it is postmodern.

Hospitals. Hospitals have likewise built new structures like the Medical City on Ortigas Ave, St Luke’s with its branch at The Fort, Cardinal Santos in San Juan, and the Asian Hospital along the SLEX. In the provinces, Cebu Doctors Hospital and Maria Reyna in Cagayan de Oro have also upgraded and built new structures. These hospitals vary in design; most are modernist, but what is common among them are the integration of new equipment and modern methods of health care and the effort to make a hospital more appealing to patients. Newer hospitals give an impression of being more like a hotel rather than a place for the infirm. Amenities such as fast-food outlets, mini-groceries, pharmacies, and an independent medical arts building for outpatients are included in the design. Depending on one’s budget, room choices can be simple like wards or suites like those in five-star hotels.

Hospitals are developing in response to advances in medicine and healthcare, especially of the aging. Also, hospital tourism is becoming common in Asia with foreigners coming to Asian hospitals for treatment or elective surgery that might be prohibitive in cost in their home country. So the atmosphere of going on vacation is best maintained.

Commercial and Related Buildings. As of 1992, high-rise buildings in Makati and Mandaluyong have reached close to or beyond 140 m. The Pacific Plaza Condominium in Makati rises to 43 stories or 130.9 m above ground level and has a four-and-a-half level basement for parking. The Palladium Summit Condominium in Mandaluyong is 138 m high and has 46 stories. The Rufino Tower, an office building in Makati, is 150 m high, including radio antenna, and has 42 stories. Fast becoming a forest of skyscrapers is Pasig, which began to develop more rapidly in the mid-1980s.

Most of the newer commercial buildings are rising in the new developments: in Mandaluyong and Pasig at the Ortigas Center and at the old site of the Rizal Capitol, at the former Fort Bonifacio and along South Luzon Expressway, from Alabang to Santa Rosa.

Stores, superstores, malls, and hotels continue to be built. Conceptually they are developments of the Fourth Republic architecture. What has characterized the Fifth Republic architecture is scale. Stores, superstores, and malls have become bigger, and are being called “mega.”

New clubhouses built in new gated villages combine a restaurant, an area for banquets and meetings, and sports facilities. Independent clubhouses apart from gated villages have also been built or upgraded like the Capitol Sports Club.

Churches. The creative impulse released by inculturation and Vatican II’s reform of the liturgy set the conditions for exploring the vernacular and the natural in Catholic church design.

The Mary Immaculate Parish Church in Moonwalk Subdivision, Las Piñas, designed by Francisco Mañosa and completed in 1988, is a tent open on all sides. The roof hangs from cables attached to concrete pylons, and is lined within by chemically treated anahaw leaves. The dove-shaped lamps hanging from the ceilings are of capiz (windowpane oysters).

For the Hacienda Rosalia at Manapla, Negros Occidental, Fr Luis Gaston built a church using discarded cartwheels. The church is unique for being made of recycled materials. It is in the neo-vernacular style.

The Benedictine Monastery Chapel of the Transfiguration in Malaybalay is the last major work of National Artist Leandro Locsin. Here he returns to the open church design he first used in the Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice in the University of the Philippines, but instead of a circular plan, he worked with a square plan. He placed the altar at one side of the square plan and covered the floor area with a pyramidal roof evocative of the bahay kubo (nipa hut) or the Ifugao fale (house). Set on the cool plateau of Bukidnon, the church harmonizes with the surroundings.

Some churches may be described as postmodern. The Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Zamboanga City designed by Abarro and Associates, 1998-2002, was built to replace the old cathedral made of wood dating to the post-World War II years. The new cathedral drew its design concept from the image of bundles of candles standing upright that devotees traditionally place on stands as votive offerings. The sculptural cathedral shows postmodernism’s tendency to find inspiration from various sources, not just architectural works.

Renamed Pedro Calungsod Chapel, after the beatification of San Pedro Calungsod was celebrated at the SM Seaside City in Talisay, Cebu, the chapel is by US-based architect Carlos Arnaiz. Sitting on a half-hectare property within SM’s development, the chapel was donated by the Sy Family to the Archdiocese of Cebu. Arnaiz designed the chapel in a sculptural manner using as a design element 100 freestanding vertical walls connected by tall expanses of glass windows in casement frames. The main chapel is complemented by a Chapel for the Blessed Sacrament and outdoor stations of the cross. The whole complex sits above a cement podium, with spaces underneath for other uses. The chapel echoes the designs of Mexican architect Luis Ramiro Barragán Mortín, who works with tall sheer walls as a design element.

Gerard Lico coined the phrase “ecclesiastical eccentricity” to describe churches that do not fit neatly into traditional forms and models of churches. The term was not limited to Catholic churches but included Protestant churches. As examples, Lico cites the neo-modernist Church of the Gesù, 2002, of the Ateneo de Manila University designed by Jose Pedro Recio and Carmelo Casas based on the pyramid; the New Millennium Evangelical Church, 2003, which resembles a six-story office building except for having a corner which tapers like a bell tower and terminates in a cross; and the Ampoanan sa Kalinaw ug Kinaadman, 2002, in the botanical garden of Southwestern University in Cebu, designed by National Artist Napoleon V. Abueva. The last is more a piece of monumental and kinetic sculpture than a building (Lico 2008, 538–42).

In contrast to the neo-vernacular, modern, and the postmodern designs is a visible return to tradition that can be called neobaroque. This trend began in the 1980s, when churches, which were otherwise modern began building retablos in the baroque style. Such projects were spurred most likely by a reaction to post-Vatican II church designs which were straightforward and functional. A common complaint was these churches did not look Catholic; they looked Protestant. The root of this trend was modernism’s adage “form follows function.” Post-Vatican II church design placed the celebration of Church rites at the center and the church building was subservient to these rites. In the modernist idiom, the church came alive when there was a celebration, otherwise it was an empty shell. But parishioners and devotees who had grown up with the opulence of baroque in old churches found the spaces dead and unappealing. Soon these rather empty churches were filled with statuary and other objects of devotion, placed in a baroque retablo inside a modernist church. Examples are found in the Antipolo Cathedral and the Sacred Heart Parish Church in Kamuning, Quezon City.

The cupola of St Peter’s Basilica in Rome was copied by St Peter’s Parish Church, established 1993. This church on Commonwealth Ave has a classical portico, reminiscent of the Madeleine in France. St Peter’s dome is also used by the Santa Rita de Montefalco church in Pasig.

New neobaroque churches were built. Publicly accessible examples are St James Parish in Alabang and the Archdiocesan Shrine of Jesus the Way, the Truth and the Life, built in 1995 near SM’s Mall of Asia. The Opus Dei built a chapel in the neobaroque style in Makati inside an office building, which is said to have been the prototype for the development of St James.

The mega church is a new development with roots in Evangelical Churches in the United States. A mega church is a worship space that can accommodate 2000 people or more for a service. A well-known example is the Crystal Cathedral in Garden Grove, Orange County, California, in the US. The reflective glass building, designed by American architect Philip Johnson, was completed in 1981 and seats 2,736 people. It was built for the Reformed Church in America founded by Dr. Robert H. Schuller in 1955. The cathedral was under the Reformed Church from 1981 to 2012. After the death of Dr Schuller, it was acquired by the Roman Catholic Church, as Schuller’s church was bankrupt and could not pay its debts. The church is undergoing renovation to be transformed into the “Christ Cathedral” of the Diocese of Orange.

From its evangelical beginnings, similar structures have been built in the Philippines, not necessarily by evangelicals but by TV preachers and churches that have large followings. El Shaddai founder Mike Velarde inaugurated a one billion peso House of Prayer on a 10-hectare property at Amvel City, San Dionisio, Parañaque. The building is 10,000 sqm with a 16,000 seating capacity and additional standing room for 25,000. It is shaped as two large concave halls intersecting each other and crowned by a glass pyramid at the center. Evangelical preacher Apollo Quiboloy broke ground in 2012 for a 50,000-seat indoor cathedral, called King Dome along the Philippine-Japan Friendship Highway, near the Davao airport. The project was expected to be finished in 2015. Externally, the dome resembles a sports stadium. On 17 Aug 2011, the INC broke ground for the Philippine Arena, completed on 27 Jul 2014, the centennial of the INC. Built on 7.5 ha of land, the dome measures 3.6 ha and about 60 m or 15 stories high.

The structure is no longer called church, sambahan or kapilya. It is a dome because, architecturally, it is a large sports stadium. The difference is that the stage, which can also be used for indoor sports, will be to one side of the dome and not in the center as expected. The off-center stage allows the use of the dome for services, concerts and other events, local or international.

Whether they adhere to revivalist styles or experiment with modern, postmodern, or contemporary design, the buildings of the Catholic Church and some Protestant churches, are characterized by diversity and individuality, and attest to the freedom that is possible within the framework of faith. While the INC churches work with its own brand of the gothic, churches of the 21st century have integrated designs incorporating the Roman arch and cast concrete embellishments in facades of a more decorative style.

Whatever be its outward form or style, the church is expected not only to provide space for worship but to inspire worship. The architecture of an epoch is an expression of its values and aspirations. Future generations viewing the church architecture of our time will judge whether or not this was a golden age of the spirit.

Theaters and Cinemas. Equipped with escalators to carry large crowds, the new movie houses have moved up from street level to the upper floors of urban buildings, while the ground floor has been given over to shops. Called multiplex, the latest movie houses can be a cluster of smaller theaters and are located on the upper or uppermost floor of shopping malls. In the 1990s, there were about 200 cinema houses in Metro Manila of varying size, levels of comfort, and degrees of architectural value. But movie houses are facing big competition with the rise of new media and the availability of videos on demand through the Internet. Many moviemaking studios have shut down and been replaced by the television studio. The grand movie houses of the pre-World War II era, the 1950s to the 1970s, have disappeared. Instead, movie houses are now functional spaces that deliver entertainment using digital technology, thus the focus is on building an environment where movie watching is comfortable.

Movie houses and theaters have also been built in entertainment complexes like Resorts World and Solaire. They are integrated into a complex with restaurants, shops, hotel, casino, and private residences.

Future Prospects. The postmodern trend has freed architecture to explore new forms and come up with creative and eye-catching solutions to architectural design. Newer methods of construction, manifesting in stronger construction steel, better formulation of cement, environmentally responsible paints that avoid toxic substance, and alternative materials that will not deplete natural resources are impacting architecture. These materials are being imported as trade becomes more open in a global market. Materials for construction can be manufactured abroad in places like Japan and Korea for projects that require special material and equipment not available and not easy to manufacture in the Philippines. The containerization of shipping allows large modular parts to be shipped to the construction site and assembled there.

The freedom to experiment and the possibilities of new material can free Philippine architecture from restrictive mindsets. The easy flow of global trends will come face to face with an enduring Filipinism and will continue to raise the question of what is Filipino in Philippine architecture. Moreover, the increasing population of the Philippines, urban migration, the rising cost of real estate caused in part by foreign investments, and the enduring presence of poor communities in urban areas will continue to challenge the ability of architects, developers, the government, and civil society to address the demand for building townscapes and architecture that are humane, protect the environment, and foster the quality of life.  Written by René B. Javellana

Related Content

article.value: Introduction

From 22-26 Feb 1986, the world was held mesmerized at the political events happening in the Philippines. On the evening of 22 Feb, Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile and Chief of Staff Gen Fidel Ramos declared that they were abandoning Pres Ferdinand Marcos and had called on the military loyal to the Republic to gather at the adjoining camps, Crame and Aguinaldo, along Epifanio de los Santos Ave (EDSA). At nine o’clock in the evening, Jaime Cardinal Sin, through Radio Veritas, urged civilians to go to EDSA and station themselves between the camps. Although the call seemed unwise and foolish, by Sunday morning the crowd had increased to the hundred thousands and, by noon of 23 Feb, Enrile crossed EDSA to consolidate his loyal troops with those of Ramos. The Veritas transmitter went dead—sabotaged, it was believed, by Marcos’s troops. But from an unknown source, known only as Radio Bandido, broadcasts supportive of the events happening at EDSA were aired nationwide. Gatherings and protests like EDSA were repeated in major cities like Cebu and Davao.

Marcos and Aquino each had their own presidential oath-takings—Aquino at the Club Filipino and Marcos at Malacañan—while the crowd at EDSA had swollen to hundreds of thousands. There were more military defections to Ramos and Enrile and, by the evening of 26 Feb, the tide of popular support had turned. Marcos and his family left Malacañan, airlifted and eventually ending at Clark Field, where the family and others who followed went to Hawaii in exile.

The euphoria of Marcos’s departure was soon replaced by the hard task of rebuilding. Aquino took steps to return to pre-martial law democracy. After appointing cabinet members, governors, and mayors to their positions, she set forth to create a Constitutional Commission which by 1987 had finished its task. Ratified by a plebiscite, the 1987 Philippine Constitution set the stage for reinstating elections and other institutions of Philippine democracy.

Aquino Presidency, 1986 – 92. The administration of Corazon C. Aquino saw the decline of Bagong Lipunan architecture. Many building projects created by Imelda went under scrutiny by the Presidential Commission on Good Government (PCGG). Some projects turned out not to have been paid for or had extensive loans from local agencies. The Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) took over the Metropolitan Theater, built with a loan from GSIS which had not been paid. Other projects, like Imelda’s resort in Olot, Fort Ilocandia, and the Marcos house in Batac, fell under government investigation. University of Life went into a decline. The Santo Niño Shrine in Tacloban was padlocked and remained unused until it was damaged by Typhoon Yolanda in Nov 2013. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the Makiling High School for the Arts continued to exist. Both had good management teams to see them through the transition to the Fifth Republic.

Aquino opted not to reside in Malacañan, choosing instead as presidential residence a guesthouse of the palace on Arlegui St, an art deco residence built before World War II. After repairing Malacañan, which was slightly damaged by the onslaught of people who entered the premises in the euphoria of People Power and after the palace furnishings had been properly inventoried, Aquino opened Malacañan as a museum that showed the opulence and decadence of the Marcos era. Under Aquino, the former San Miguel Brewery, acquired during the Marcos era, was refurbished to serve as the new Executive House. The 1921 Executive House was renamed Kalayaan Hall.

In 1987, Aquino established the Presidential Commission for Culture and the Arts (PCCA), predecessor of National Commission for Culture and the Arts, to oversee the art and culture field. In the CCP, a new team took over, reorganized the center to serve all the arts except architecture, and pursued the thrusts of Filipinization, democratization, and decentralization.

The Aquino presidency was plagued with many difficulties. The government was bankrupt. The national debt was increasing and the economy was in bad state. A series of brownouts signaled the problems left by the Marcos era. The Aquino presidency was beset by coup d’etat attempts by military factions which had supported her bid for presidency but were critical of the slow pace that she took to achieve the reform she had promised. Factions still loyal to Marcos, especially from his political bailiwick in the Ilocos, launched protests against Aquino.

Although it was not a good time for architecture, the regime managed to address the need for improving roads and building flyovers to ease traffic in and out of Manila and set the stage for future development by signing into law the creation of the Bases Conversion and Development Authority (BCDA). Republic Act (RA) 7227, BCDA, was signed on 13 Mar 1992, a few months before the next presidential election. Although RA 7227 was amended by RA 7917 in 1995 and by RA 9400 in 2007, the rationale for the act remained. BCDA was an instrument of government with corporate powers “mandated to transform former US military bases into alternative productive civilian use” (http://www.bcda.gov.ph/). BCDA contributed to the modernization of the Armed Forces of the Philippines and worked towered socio-economic development.

Ramos Presidency, 1992 – 98. The building boom came later, during the presidency of Fidel Ramos. Ramos, who succeeded Aquino, restored Malacañan to its former function by returning to Malacañan and using Marcos’s office. He repaired the palace, which had been damaged by typhoons.

But the strongest effect of the Ramos presidency was opening the Philippine economy to more foreign investments under the aegis of greater regional cooperation. Under Ramos, BCDA moved forward. The Americans, who had left their bases at Subic Bay and Clark Field after they were devastated by the eruption of Mt Pinatubo on 15 Jun 1991, left behind large tracts of land leased from the Philippines but which had expired. The Philippines did not renew the lease.

Subic and Clark were contiguous to each other and were damaged by heavy ash fall. The recreational Camp John Hay in Baguio was returned to the Philippines with the exit of the American military. Under Ramos, these former American bases were opened for developers who would sign contracts for 25 years to develop the place following terms set by law. The amendments to the law allowed the redevelopment of other military bases. Aside from Subic, Clark, and John Hay, BCDA covers the Bataan Technology Park, Poro Point, Fort Bonifacio, and Villamor Airbase. Because it was located in the area of Metro Manila (NCR), straddling Makati City and Taguig City, Fort Bonifacio (formerly McKinley), is the most visible area of development. The conversion of the bases and other government lands became the focus of the government’s development project.

Government derived income from the sale or rental of these large facilities to private investors, and with money from foreign investors, created virtually new cities made up of high rise buildings. High-rises of multiple use were the buildings of choice because of the rising value of real estate, especially of properties near or within the ambit of the metropolis. The government also launched a BOT (build-operate-transfer) scheme where an investor was allowed to develop public land and property for a set period like 25 years, enough time to recoup investment and make profit. Thenthe development would revert to the government.

During the Aquino presidency, a privatization program was initiated with the sale of 122 government-owned companies, bringing the Philippine government $2 billion. Under Ramos, privatization was expanded into infrastructure. To solve the recurring electrical shortages and resulting brownouts, Ramos moved to privatize the generation and distribution of electricity from 1992 to 1994. Seeing the success of this scheme, the next to be privatized was the Metropolitan Water and Sewerage System (MWSS), a government entity established before World War II. MWSS went into partnership with Manila Water and Maynilad in 1997 to upgrade and expand the distribution system of water in Metro Manila, Cavite, and Laguna.

Economic growth characterized the Ramos years and spurred confidence that the Philippines was now on the road to recovery. New developments and new buildings rose not only in Manila but also in the provinces. Development was undertaken by large real estate companies. In the lead was Ayala, which had a long history of real estate development. They were among the first to locate at Fort Bonifacio, which was adjacent to Forbes Park.

Other developers entered the market. SM created SM Development Corporation (SMDC). The Robinson’s group, Villar, Fil Estate, Millennium and many more realty and architectural development companies invested in the bases. Much of development was controlled by large corporations that could bring in foreign investors and had the means to market to foreign buyers, like Filipinos living abroad or to foreign companies that were looking for a base in Southeast Asia.

Under Ramos, a 17-hectare development in Bagumbayan or Libis, Quezon City was launched in 1997. This would be known as Eastwood City. Within the development is Cyberpark, an information technology (IT) center approved by the Philippine Economic Zone Authority (PEZA). An agency under the Department of Trade and Industry, PEZA was enacted under RA 7916, and signed into law by Ramos in 1995. PEZA is mandated to promote investment in export-oriented industry in the country and to assist investors. It facilitates the establishment of IT companies in business processing outsourcing (BPO) and in knowledge processing outsourcing. It also encourages the establishment of special economic zones of businesses in tourism, medical tourism, logistics and warehousing, and economic zone development and operation.

The biggest government-sponsored project was the construction of the Centennial Park in Clark Field, Pampanga, built during the Ramos presidency. Set to open in 1996 to commemorate the centennial of the Philippine Revolution, the park consisted of manmade islands and water features that combined elements of a museum with a theme park. The Centennial Park was a white elephant. It was not completed and very few went to the park.

The Philippines, through the able fiscal management of the Ramos regime, sailed through the Asian economic crisis of 1992, unlike neighboring parts of Southeast Asiawhere the economic bubble burst that sent most of the region in a downward spin.

Estrada Presidency, 1998 – 2001. The presidency was brief, a little more than two years, 30 Jun 1998 to 20 Jan 2001. Ramos’s successor Joseph Estrada decided to take residence at the Premier Guest House and improved it as a residence and office. The interior of Malacañan was refurbished.

The Estrada presidency was not able to hold on to the economic gains of the Ramos era. Riddled with charges of corruption and plunder and criticized for its informal style of governing, Estrada soon found himself the subject of an impeachment proceeding but resigned from office before the trial could conclude. He was ousted from power by People Power II when the impeachment court decided not to present vital evidence against Estrada and massive protests against Estrada gained momentum.

Despite its brevity, it was under Estrada’s administration that Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) 2 was completed and inaugurated. This project began during the Ramos presidency. But soon after the inauguration, Estrada was embroiled in controversy connected with this very project because he awarded the use of the new terminal to Philippine Airlines, whose majority stockholder, Lucio Tan, was said to be one of Estrada’s supporters. Although the law creating PEZA was signed by Ramos in 1997, it is to Estrada’s credit that the Philippines became a major player in the emerging business process outsourcing (BPO), popularly known as “call centers.” It was during his presidency that the Eastwood City became operational. It was the prototype of the cyber city that was to emerge at Fort Bonifacio and the provinces of the Visayas, like Iloilo, Bacolod, and Cebu, and of Mindanao, like Davao, and cities like Baguio.
Arroyo Presidency, 2001 – 10. Upon Estrada’s resignation, vice-president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo took office as president, as mandated by law.

With great effort and sound management, Arroyo was able to slow down the economic decline of the Estrada years. As in the Estrada years, government was not into architecture, although Arroyo renovated Malacañan, cleaning out the personal effects of the Marcos family and turning them over to the PCGG. She had a Presidential Briefing Room similar to the White House Situation Room built. She recovered historic furniture, restored Kalayaan Hall, and spruced up the garden.

Arroyo focused on projects that would spur economic growth, so her regime was known for increasing infrastructure, like improving roads, building new highways, and opening sea lanes by integrating roll on-roll off (RoRo) shipping through the improvement of ports and the construction of new ones. Arroyo left a master plan for infrastructure improvement, which included the rehabilitation and expansion of the railroad system, a task given to Vice-Pres Noli de Castro; the expansion of the North Luzon and South Luzon Expressways (NLEX and SLEX) connecting Metro Manila with the provinces; the construction of the Manila Bay highway, a project that was in the original Burnham plan for Manila; and the development of areas surrounding the NCR. Under her many infrastructure projects were launched, including the upgrade of NLEX and SLEX, the construction of NAIA III and similar airport projects in the Visayas and Mindanao, like the new airports at Santa Barbara, Iloilo and Silay City, Negros Occidental, Zamboanga City, and the Cagayan de Oro airport.

Under Arroyo, part of the military base fronting NAIA III was redeveloped as Resorts World, a complex consisting of a hotel, casino, stores, restaurants, movie houses, and theaters. It was inaugurated in 2009 and was the first of the casino resorts to be built.

Benigno Aquino III Presidency, 2010 - 16. The first two years of Benigno Aquino’s presidency was marked by a slowdown in government-sponsored projects. Working with a program of “Daang Matuwid,” a slogan addressing corruption, Aquino had the infrastructure programs of Arroyo scrutinized. This meant that very little was done during the first two years of his administration. NAIA III went under review. The rehabilitation of the northern track of a railroad system that was to connect Manila with the Ilocos was a dead project. The contract for the railroad was allegedly flawed and China which was to be a partner in developing the railroad was no longer with the project. Informal settlers began to slowly return to the land that had been cleared for the railroad’s right of way. The building and expansion of piers and harbors—part of Arroyo’s scheme to promote and develop roro shipping—was put on hold.

Only after this period of examination did the government continue with projects that had been in the works since Arroyo. Under Aquino, NAIA III, which had been embroiled in controversy with contractors, became partially operational by 2008, and fully operational in 2011. Projects like road development, which had been developed under Arroyo, continued.

In the cultural field, the Aquino administration invested heavily in the upgrading and expansion of the National Museum of the Philippines. With Aquino, the old Legislative Building, which housed the office of the Prime Minister called Executive House under Marcos, was turned over totally to the National Museum. Following a master plan drawn during the Ramos regime, the Legislative Building became the National Museum’s Museum of Fine Arts. The Department of Tourism building (in pre-World War II period, the Department of Agriculture building) was turned over to the National Museum to turn into a Museum of Natural History, to be completed in 2017. Other museum branches were repaired, upgraded, and built. The Batanes Museum was built in a former American military base on Batan Island. Convention centers, like that of Iloilo City, were also completed.

During the Aquino presidency, two integrated resort and casino complexes were opened in a 120-ha reclamation area of Manila Bay within the jurisdiction of Parañaque. Solaire opened in 2013 and City of Dreams in 2015. Both developments are within the Entertainment City of the Philippine Amusement Gaming Corporation (PAGCOR) which was designated as a special economic zone by PEZA under a presidential proclamation in 2009 by Pres Arroyo. Solaire started construction in Jun 2010. The first phase completed in 2013 was inaugurated with Pres Aquino in attendance. City of Dreams, which had a sister company in Macau, rests on a 6.2-hectare property; it opened in Feb 2015.

Globalization and Architectural Development. Globalization as a process of international integration arising from the interchange of world views, ideas, products, labor, capital and other resources has its antecedents in the 19th century when imperialist nations dominated and exploited Asia, Africa, and Latin America. Advances in transportation and communication facilitated this domination. With the revolutions for independence, the Western empires collapsed but the newly independent nations were integrated into a web of exchange— economic, social, and cultural. In the 20th century, globalization grew at an increasingly fast pace as advances in container ships, fast trains, jet liners, and the development of mobile phones and the internet built a more connected world. In 2000, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) defined four basic aspects of globalization: capital and investment movements, trade and transactions, migration, and knowledge dissemination.

Closely allied to globalization is transnationalism or transnationalization. In economic terms, it involves the organization of production, where various stages of production take place in various countries to cut cost and maximize productivity.

Green or sustainable architecture, while not representing a specific style, is a global movement that grew out of the rising concern about the environment and its degradation due to human activity. Its origins are in the energy crisis and environmental pollution in the United States in the 1960s and the 1970s. Rachel Carson’s Silent Spring, 1962, is considered as the first to articulate sustainable development with green architecture. With the spread of the environment movement from the United States to the rest of the world grew the movement of “green architecture,” which sought to mitigate the effects of architecture on the environment. The move was to reduce the use of energy in the construction, maintenance, and use of the building. Also of concern were how materials were used, how they were extracted, how much energy was used to make them or what their “carbon footprint” was, and whether the materials used—whether natural or composite made in factories—had an adverse effect on the environment.

These initiatives of green architecture were preventive or curative but a more active phase of green architecture looked into the generation of power through alternative means like solar energy, the increase of green spaces through lighted interiors that allowed the cultivation of plants known to purify the air, and by rooftop and vertical gardens. A local green architecture evaluation and certification group is Berde. An international certification group is LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environment Design). Both are actively working to evaluate buildings and rate them. LEED uses a standard symbolized by precious metals, platinum being the highest rating given.

Philippine Response to International Trends. Much of the architectural development at this time fell to the private business sector. In general, since the Ramos administration, government has left business to take care of itself concentrating its interventions indirectly, through tax cuts and investments initiatives.

With the development of digital technology and other means of communication, the Filipinos’ proficiency in English and their ability to mimic various English accents, the Philippines took the lead in the international market in offering BPO services. This spurred the growth of the Ortigas Business Center and Libis in the boundaries of Quezon City and Manila. C5, the fifth of Metro Manila’s circumferential road, linked Libis, Ortigas, The Fort and the international airport, and became a corridor of development and high-rises. Some high-rises were offices, many for call centers, others residences, and still others for mixed use with parking at the basement or above ground, retail outlets, restaurants and convenience stores at the ground, office spaces in the lower stories, and residences at the upper stories. A common configuration was to limit retail spaces and offices to a podium, whose roof was landscaped as a garden, and to build a residential tower above the podium.

Because the Philippines was opening to a global market, the construction of an “iconic building,” designed by a world-renowned architect to attract international investors became attractive. Iconic refers to a building which is unique in design and has the stamp of its creator, an internationally known and admired architect. Although Michael Graves had antedated him in a project at Binondo, American Chinese architect I. M. Pei’s Essensa Towers, a residential high-rise for the high-end market at Fort Bonifacio was seen as a first in a series of iconic buildings.

Clients or developers justified hiring foreign consultants or architects on the grounds that the needed expertise for design and construction was not locally available. A local firm would form a partnership with a foreign company and in this way internationally known architects and firms entered the Philippines. Such firms and their projects include Michael Graves, World Trade Exchange, 1996, in Binondo; I. M. Pei (Pei, Cobb, Freed & Partners), Essensa Towers, 2001; KPF (Kohn, Pendersen, and Fox), LKG Tower, 1998; and SOM (Skidmore, Owings and Merril), Yuchengco Towers, 2001. Other foreign firms that partnered with Filipinos are HOK (Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum), Gensler, NBBJ, RTLK, and Arquitectura (Lico 2008, 510).

Globalization also meant that the new buildings had to be up to international standards. To ensure that quality, the Ayala Corp. had its own core of engineers and contractors, and soon other companies like SM and Villar had their own. These companies either had in-house teams of architects, engineers, landscape designers, and interior designers or worked with a set team. It had its own workforce of licensed plumbers, electricians, carpenters, painters, and a host of manual laborers.

Styles and Postmodernism. While the Philippines was going through political upheavals in the 1970s, there was a different upheaval in architecture. Although its conceptual origins can be traced to the late 1950s and 1960s, when its early pioneer, Robert Venturi, reintroduced the split gable in the Vanna Venturi house in 1964 and wrote a critique of modern architecture, postmodernism did not become a movement until the 1970s when postmodernist architecture came to prominence.

Postmodernism is the term used to define a worldview that has turned away from modernism’s accent on rationality, professionalization, industrialization, urbanization, secularization, order, and hierarchy in the newly formed nation-state, capitalism,and the market economy. Belief in constant change that leads to progress was a key element in the modern mindset. This was the guiding philosophy of Europe before World War II, buoyed by spectacular growth brought about by science and technology. But philosophers critiqued the possibility of absolute and total knowledge, and the claims of positivist science and philosophies like Marxism, which saw the inexorable progress from capitalism to socialism to communism. World War II and the detonation of the atomic bomb at Hiroshima and Nagasaki shook the world’s confidence in inevitable progress. The era after World War II culminating in the 1980s is seen as the last phase of modernism.

Postmodernism in architecture or postmodernist architecture does not represent one style—it is rather a perspective on architecture that has embraced a host of styles. Postmodernist architects regarded modern architecture as lacking in soul and imagination and unable to achieve the Utopia it promised. Working from Le Corbusier’s concept of a building as a machine for living, its attempted harmony of form and function, and the dismissal of ornament, the modernist strain produced boxy edifices which looked like clones of each other. The postmodernist wanted to return wit and ornament and to return architecture to its roots by referencing historical architecture. One of its vocal theoreticians, Venturi, coined the saying “less is a bore” in response to modernist Ludwig Mies van der Rohe “less is more.” Early examples of postmodernism are Michael Graves’ Portland Bldg and Philip Johnson’s Sony Bldg (formerly AT&T) in New York. Instead of the flat roof of modernism, it used a broken pediment derived from classicism. It also adapted furniture during the Renaissance and Baroque periods.

An early example of postmodernism in the Philippines is Gabriel Formoso’s Pacific Star Building, in Makati, completed in 1990. While distinctively modern, Pacific Star evokes the past by paying homage to the Roman arch, and does so with refinement and grace. Other postmodern buildings are Rogelio Villarosa’s King’s Court, 1990, Tektite Tower, 1995, and Renaissance Tower, 1995; Felino Palafox’s Nueva Ecija Capitol at Palayan City, 2003; and Dewey Santos and Felix Ngo’s designs for Metrobank branches (beginning in the late 1990s), where no two branches are alike. Ritcheto Alcordo’s Waterfront Hotel in Lahug Cebu, 1998, has turrets making it resemble a cartoon-like fairy tale castle. Sanctuarium, 2006, the largest columbarium in the Philippines, has a temple facade surmounted by a translucent dome.

Postmodernism had its impact on residential styles. Following the eclecticism of postmodern architectures, new developments, especially in vacation areas like Tagaytay, followed a theme development plan, landscaping, and architecture. Designs could derive from the Swiss chalet, the Greek residences of Santorini, Mediterranean, or Mexican houses, especially in its palette of contrasting, vibrant colors. There was a market for such styles as Filipinos traveled for leisure or as overseas workers.

A popular style of residential architecture has been described as “Zen.” These are modernist and postmodernist structures characterized by straight lines and restrained color schemes, usually earth-brown, black, white, and gray. Zen architecture modernizes many of the elements of the traditional Philippine house with its expanses of large windows, overhangs, and an interaction between the outdoors and indoors.

Postmodernism has been criticized, especially by the modernist, as being eclectic, filled with useless ornaments, and elements that have no function, therefore a needless expense and waste. It has also been described as stick-on-style: that is, a modernist building may be clad with precast ornaments or faux stones that quote some historical style. What began as an avant-garde movement has unfortunately been appropriated in designs that “seldom had the finesse and beauty of the original for they were reduced to an eclectic visual feast processed in the name of populism and consumerism,” writes Lico.

Although the qualities of good architecture are undermined in poorly planned projects, the postmodern creative spirit has shaped the Philippine architecture of the 1990s and the first two decades of the 21st century.

article.value: Forms

Dwellings and Residences. High-rise condominiums and gated communities are characteristic of the Fifth Republic era. High-rise condominiums were already built during the Fourth Republic and gated subdivisions emerged during the post-World War II era. What characterizes the Fifth Republic condominiums are their height and proliferation, and the gated communities, their more comprehensive planning and proliferation as new “villages” were built farther away from Metro Manila’s center. Quezon City, Valenzuela City, Laguna, and Cavite were all sites of development. In the provinces, Cebu’s development sprawled south to Talisay and north to Liloan. Iloilo’s development moved north toward Pavia. Cagayan de Oro’s development spread across the highway that linked Cagayan with Iligan and Gingoog. Davao’s sprawl moved north following the Pan-Philippine Highway, through Matina, Lanang, and the direction of the Davao International Airport, and toward Talomo and Dumoy. Baguio also opened new developments in Asin for instance and large tracks of land like Camp John Hay and Brent School have been the centers of development.

While the gated community concept remains essentially the same as it was in the 1960s, namely, a self-contained community secured by walls and gates, what distinguished the new developments were: first, they were developed following an economic scale from low-end to high-end; and second, unlike in the 1960s, where house lots were sold, many developments followed the Philamlife model where pre-existing houses were built and priced accordingly.

Mass Housing. The government continued to face the problem of growing population and the need for mass housing. While government continued with projects to build low-cost housing during the Fifth Republic era, private groups became active in upgrading and building low-cost housing. The Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) initiated housing projects for its members, for instance, in Rodriguez (formerly Montalban), Rizal. Habitat for Humanity has been active in housing. Gawad Kalinga, a local organization, has also been working with mass housing. Entering a shanty village, Gawad Kalinga first organizes the people, especially the men who are invited to help in building better houses, through “sweat equity,” that is offering free labor in exchange for better houses. Houses are sponsored by donors like schools and companies, and individual donors. The building blocks of the houses like beams and hollow blocks are prepared in the area with the cooperation of the residents. Gawad Kalinga houses are known for their colorful exteriors and for the common facilities, like a hall for meetings and for communal work. Gawad Kalinga has also launched a livelihood program to help in the upkeep of the residences built and help uplift the poor communities.

Government Office Buildings. With the devolution of governance to the local government, the national government has not built much. When the Senate was convened in accordance with the 1987 constitution that reinstated the bicameral legislature, the lower house went to the Batasang Pambansa and the upper house eventually to the GSIS building in the reclamation area along Manila Bay. The old Legislative building was turned over to the National Museum, as well as the nearby buildings known in the pre-World War II era as Agriculture and Finance.

The local government was more active in building. New city halls were built, in places like Urdaneta, Pangasinan, and the old city hall was converted to other uses like museums. Felino Palafox Jr’s design for the Nueva Ecija Capitol at Palayan City works with a severe interpretation of classicism with its arched windows and pillars. William Coscolluela designed the new Iloilo Capitol in harmony with the neoclassical heritage Capitol near it.

Schools. Private schools were in the forefront of developing new campuses outside the metropolis. San Juan de Letran, Brent School, Xavier School, Miriam (formerly Maryknoll), and Lyceum are some of the schools that have opened or are opening satellite campuses near or within new developments like Nuvali along the Santa Rosa-Tagaytay road. New schools like STI, AMA, Adventist, and others have also opened countryside campuses.
