article.value: The trend is not limited to Metro Manila as provincial schools seek larger campuses, like Sacred Heart School in Cebu, which moved from its crowded midtown Cebu campus to Mandaue and Xavier University in Cagayan de Oro, which developed a new campus plus housing in the uplands of Cagayan in the direction of the former Lumbia Airport.

These countryside campuses, like Lyceum at Laguna, Batangas, and Cavite, offer the advantage of a wide campus opened to the countryside. Formerly Lyceum Institute of Technology, Lyceum Batangas was incorporated on 18 Jan 2000. Encompassing five colleges and an international school, Lyceum Cavite Campus in General Trias, established in 2008, is dubbed as the “first and only resort campus” in the Philippines because it integrates landscaping with the campus design. Gardens and pools are integral to the complex. The complex’s design is derived from the laurel leaf, a reference to the Laurel family who established the Lyceum chain. The leaf design is expressed in a canopy of curving roofs that serve as a shield against sun and rain for the buildings underneath. This canopy is supported by a steel structure independent of the building. In spirit it is postmodern.

Hospitals. Hospitals have likewise built new structures like the Medical City on Ortigas Ave, St Luke’s with its branch at The Fort, Cardinal Santos in San Juan, and the Asian Hospital along the SLEX. In the provinces, Cebu Doctors Hospital and Maria Reyna in Cagayan de Oro have also upgraded and built new structures. These hospitals vary in design; most are modernist, but what is common among them are the integration of new equipment and modern methods of health care and the effort to make a hospital more appealing to patients. Newer hospitals give an impression of being more like a hotel rather than a place for the infirm. Amenities such as fast-food outlets, mini-groceries, pharmacies, and an independent medical arts building for outpatients are included in the design. Depending on one’s budget, room choices can be simple like wards or suites like those in five-star hotels.

Hospitals are developing in response to advances in medicine and healthcare, especially of the aging. Also, hospital tourism is becoming common in Asia with foreigners coming to Asian hospitals for treatment or elective surgery that might be prohibitive in cost in their home country. So the atmosphere of going on vacation is best maintained.

Commercial and Related Buildings. As of 1992, high-rise buildings in Makati and Mandaluyong have reached close to or beyond 140 m. The Pacific Plaza Condominium in Makati rises to 43 stories or 130.9 m above ground level and has a four-and-a-half level basement for parking. The Palladium Summit Condominium in Mandaluyong is 138 m high and has 46 stories. The Rufino Tower, an office building in Makati, is 150 m high, including radio antenna, and has 42 stories. Fast becoming a forest of skyscrapers is Pasig, which began to develop more rapidly in the mid-1980s.

Most of the newer commercial buildings are rising in the new developments: in Mandaluyong and Pasig at the Ortigas Center and at the old site of the Rizal Capitol, at the former Fort Bonifacio and along South Luzon Expressway, from Alabang to Santa Rosa.

Stores, superstores, malls, and hotels continue to be built. Conceptually they are developments of the Fourth Republic architecture. What has characterized the Fifth Republic architecture is scale. Stores, superstores, and malls have become bigger, and are being called “mega.”

New clubhouses built in new gated villages combine a restaurant, an area for banquets and meetings, and sports facilities. Independent clubhouses apart from gated villages have also been built or upgraded like the Capitol Sports Club.
Churches. The creative impulse released by inculturation and Vatican II’s reform of the liturgy set the conditions for exploring the vernacular and the natural in Catholic church design.

The Mary Immaculate Parish Church in Moonwalk Subdivision, Las Piñas, designed by Francisco Mañosa and completed in 1988, is a tent open on all sides. The roof hangs from cables attached to concrete pylons, and is lined within by chemically treated anahaw leaves. The dove-shaped lamps hanging from the ceilings are of capiz (windowpane oysters).

For the Hacienda Rosalia at Manapla, Negros Occidental, Fr Luis Gaston built a church using discarded cartwheels. The church is unique for being made of recycled materials. It is in the neo-vernacular style.

The Benedictine Monastery Chapel of the Transfiguration in Malaybalay is the last major work of National Artist Leandro Locsin. Here he returns to the open church design he first used in the Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice in the University of the Philippines, but instead of a circular plan, he worked with a square plan. He placed the altar at one side of the square plan and covered the floor area with a pyramidal roof evocative of the bahay kubo (nipa hut) or the Ifugao fale (house). Set on the cool plateau of Bukidnon, the church harmonizes with the surroundings.

Some churches may be described as postmodern. The Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Zamboanga City designed by Abarro and Associates, 1998-2002, was built to replace the old cathedral made of wood dating to the post-World War II years. The new cathedral drew its design concept from the image of bundles of candles standing upright that devotees traditionally place on stands as votive offerings. The sculptural cathedral shows postmodernism’s tendency to find inspiration from various sources, not just architectural works.

Renamed Pedro Calungsod Chapel, after the beatification of San Pedro Calungsod was celebrated at the SM Seaside City in Talisay, Cebu, the chapel is by US-based architect Carlos Arnaiz. Sitting on a half-hectare property within SM’s development, the chapel was donated by the Sy Family to the Archdiocese of Cebu. Arnaiz designed the chapel in a sculptural manner using as a design element 100 freestanding vertical walls connected by tall expanses of glass windows in casement frames. The main chapel is complemented by a Chapel for the Blessed Sacrament and outdoor stations of the cross. The whole complex sits above a cement podium, with spaces underneath for other uses. The chapel echoes the designs of Mexican architect Luis Ramiro Barragán Mortín, who works with tall sheer walls as a design element.

Gerard Lico coined the phrase “ecclesiastical eccentricity” to describe churches that do not fit neatly into traditional forms and models of churches. The term was not limited to Catholic churches but included Protestant churches. As examples, Lico cites the neo-modernist Church of the Gesù, 2002, of the Ateneo de Manila University designed by Jose Pedro Recio and Carmelo Casas based on the pyramid; the New Millennium Evangelical Church, 2003, which resembles a six-story office building except for having a corner which tapers like a bell tower and terminates in a cross; and the Ampoanan sa Kalinaw ug Kinaadman, 2002, in the botanical garden of Southwestern University in Cebu, designed by National Artist Napoleon V. Abueva. The last is more a piece of monumental and kinetic sculpture than a building (Lico 2008, 538–42).

In contrast to the neo-vernacular, modern, and the postmodern designs is a visible return to tradition that can be called neobaroque. This trend began in the 1980s, when churches, which were otherwise modern began building retablos in the baroque style. Such projects were spurred most likely by a reaction to post-Vatican II church designs which were straightforward and functional. A common complaint was these churches did not look Catholic; they looked Protestant. The root of this trend was modernism’s adage “form follows function.” Post-Vatican II church design placed the celebration of Church rites at the center and the church building was subservient to these rites. In the modernist idiom, the church came alive when there was a celebration, otherwise it was an empty shell. But parishioners and devotees who had grown up with the opulence of baroque in old churches found the spaces dead and unappealing. Soon these rather empty churches were filled with statuary and other objects of devotion, placed in a baroque retablo inside a modernist church. Examples are found in the Antipolo Cathedral and the Sacred Heart Parish Church in Kamuning, Quezon City.

The cupola of St Peter’s Basilica in Rome was copied by St Peter’s Parish Church, established 1993. This church on Commonwealth Ave has a classical portico, reminiscent of the Madeleine in France. St Peter’s dome is also used by the Santa Rita de Montefalco church in Pasig.

New neobaroque churches were built. Publicly accessible examples are St James Parish in Alabang and the Archdiocesan Shrine of Jesus the Way, the Truth and the Life, built in 1995 near SM’s Mall of Asia. The Opus Dei built a chapel in the neobaroque style in Makati inside an office building, which is said to have been the prototype for the development of St James.

The mega church is a new development with roots in Evangelical Churches in the United States. A mega church is a worship space that can accommodate 2000 people or more for a service. A well-known example is the Crystal Cathedral in Garden Grove, Orange County, California, in the US. The reflective glass building, designed by American architect Philip Johnson, was completed in 1981 and seats 2,736 people. It was built for the Reformed Church in America founded by Dr. Robert H. Schuller in 1955. The cathedral was under the Reformed Church from 1981 to 2012. After the death of Dr Schuller, it was acquired by the Roman Catholic Church, as Schuller’s church was bankrupt and could not pay its debts. The church is undergoing renovation to be transformed into the “Christ Cathedral” of the Diocese of Orange.

From its evangelical beginnings, similar structures have been built in the Philippines, not necessarily by evangelicals but by TV preachers and churches that have large followings. El Shaddai founder Mike Velarde inaugurated a one billion peso House of Prayer on a 10-hectare property at Amvel City, San Dionisio, Parañaque. The building is 10,000 sqm with a 16,000 seating capacity and additional standing room for 25,000. It is shaped as two large concave halls intersecting each other and crowned by a glass pyramid at the center. Evangelical preacher Apollo Quiboloy broke ground in 2012 for a 50,000-seat indoor cathedral, called King Dome along the Philippine-Japan Friendship Highway, near the Davao airport. The project was expected to be finished in 2015. Externally, the dome resembles a sports stadium. On 17 Aug 2011, the INC broke ground for the Philippine Arena, completed on 27 Jul 2014, the centennial of the INC. Built on 7.5 ha of land, the dome measures 3.6 ha and about 60 m or 15 stories high.

The structure is no longer called church, sambahan or kapilya. It is a dome because, architecturally, it is a large sports stadium. The difference is that the stage, which can also be used for indoor sports, will be to one side of the dome and not in the center as expected. The off-center stage allows the use of the dome for services, concerts and other events, local or international.

Whether they adhere to revivalist styles or experiment with modern, postmodern, or contemporary design, the buildings of the Catholic Church and some Protestant churches, are characterized by diversity and individuality, and attest to the freedom that is possible within the framework of faith. While the INC churches work with its own brand of the gothic, churches of the 21st century have integrated designs incorporating the Roman arch and cast concrete embellishments in facades of a more decorative style.

Whatever be its outward form or style, the church is expected not only to provide space for worship but to inspire worship. The architecture of an epoch is an expression of its values and aspirations. Future generations viewing the church architecture of our time will judge whether or not this was a golden age of the spirit.

Theaters and Cinemas. Equipped with escalators to carry large crowds, the new movie houses have moved up from street level to the upper floors of urban buildings, while the ground floor has been given over to shops. Called multiplex, the latest movie houses can be a cluster of smaller theaters and are located on the upper or uppermost floor of shopping malls. In the 1990s, there were about 200 cinema houses in Metro Manila of varying size, levels of comfort, and degrees of architectural value. But movie houses are facing big competition with the rise of new media and the availability of videos on demand through the Internet. Many moviemaking studios have shut down and been replaced by the television studio. The grand movie houses of the pre-World War II era, the 1950s to the 1970s, have disappeared. Instead, movie houses are now functional spaces that deliver entertainment using digital technology, thus the focus is on building an environment where movie watching is comfortable.

Movie houses and theaters have also been built in entertainment complexes like Resorts World and Solaire. They are integrated into a complex with restaurants, shops, hotel, casino, and private residences.

Future Prospects. The postmodern trend has freed architecture to explore new forms and come up with creative and eye-catching solutions to architectural design. Newer methods of construction, manifesting in stronger construction steel, better formulation of cement, environmentally responsible paints that avoid toxic substance, and alternative materials that will not deplete natural resources are impacting architecture. These materials are being imported as trade becomes more open in a global market. Materials for construction can be manufactured abroad in places like Japan and Korea for projects that require special material and equipment not available and not easy to manufacture in the Philippines. The containerization of shipping allows large modular parts to be shipped to the construction site and assembled there.

The freedom to experiment and the possibilities of new material can free Philippine architecture from restrictive mindsets. The easy flow of global trends will come face to face with an enduring Filipinism and will continue to raise the question of what is Filipino in Philippine architecture. Moreover, the increasing population of the Philippines, urban migration, the rising cost of real estate caused in part by foreign investments, and the enduring presence of poor communities in urban areas will continue to challenge the ability of architects, developers, the government, and civil society to address the demand for building townscapes and architecture that are humane, protect the environment, and foster the quality of life.

text:
Sections

The Indigenous Tradition
The Hispanic Tradition
The American Colonial Tradition
The Period of the Republics

Topography, survival, and defense needs, opportunities for trade and agriculture, and a people’s world view and beliefs, all contribute to the shape of the communities they live in.

The Indigenous Tradition

Perhaps the most primitive form of settlement can be found among nomadic groups like the Aeta of Northern Luzon. During certain seasons of the year, their wanderings bring them to the shore where they fish and make salt. During their sojourn, the Aeta build windscreens, called dait-dait, in clusters showing no predetermined pattern.

A developed form of settlement already existed in prehispanic Philippines. The patterns of such settlements can be gleaned from the accounts of friar missionaries as well as from archaeology. Both demonstrate that communities living in riverine areas or along the littoral built their homes in a linear rather than compact pattern. The settlement of prehispanic Cebu is a good example. Although the Jesuit Pedro Chirino reports that the settlement of Cebu stretched from what today would be downtown Cebu to Mandaue, the houses were not built in compact arrangements but rather strung along the seashore. However, there would be some massing of houses around the residence of an important personage like a datu (Hutteter 1973).

The village of Rajah Sulayman in Manila seems to have been of a different pattern. Essentially a trading center at the mouth of the Pasig, the main feature of the settlement was the fort in which was found the residence of the rajah. Houses clustered around this fort.

Settlements were generally dispersed. Casiño speculates that migrants from Java, Sumatra, and coastal Indochina were people fleeing from dynastic struggles and persecution. Coming upon a “true tropical frontier,” they saw “no need or pressure to crowd in centers with central organization” (Casiño 1977, 747). Hence, the dispersed pattern of settlements. Although dispersed, communities communicated with one another by utilizing seas, rivers, and other waterways. Inhabitants of the Philippines were expert seamen and shipwrights who built boats for travel, trade, and battle. Mountains and mountain ranges often proved to be insurmountable barriers; thus, no extensive road systems connected villages within the same island. Settlements on opposing shores of neighboring islands had better communications than those within the same island but separated by natural barriers.

The linear and the clustering pattern of settlements persists today. Hart, documenting the Cebuano dwellings in Caticugan, Negros in 1959, remarks that, overall, settlement patterns are a result of the interaction of four factors: topography, land use, the apprehension of the supernatural, and inheritance rules. Hart remarks that the last two factors figure more strongly in the formation of settlements. He documents three patterns: houses lining the main path or the linear pattern; houses encircling the community school; and houses in clusters. What holds these units together are blood ties. Houses are built at some distance from each other to allow the free circulation of air.

The linear pattern is also seen in southern Philippines. The settlement found in Barrio Luas, Parang, Sulu is typical. Houses are built along the main road, which follows the contour of the shore and one perpendicular to it. Some houses stand on stilts in the sea. A clustering of houses is found at the intersection of roads, near the wharf. Here the market, mosque, town hall, and Philippine Constabulary Camp are located. The clustering of houses near the wharf is dictated by trade. Here boats from other islands dock. Away from the road are clusters of houses (Klassen 1987).

The Ifugao of the Cordilleras do not build large towns but rather have small villages with 7 to 87 dwellings, built in small groves near their rice fields and terraces. The sites chosen for habitation are those unfit for planting because they may be rocky. There are no streets in such settlements, and the houses are not arranged in straight rows even if the form of the terrace may dictate that they should be. Villages are not surrounded by fences, although the well-to-do may have fences of runo (cane grass), stone walls, cacti or sticks and branches as barriers. In 1906, Worcester reported, on the other hand, that the Kalinga had houses placed together and often built in inaccessible spots. Surrounded by windbreaks of bamboo, these houses were raised several meters above the ground.

Lowland Filipinos, when building a bahay kubo (nipa hut), which is a new structure added to a settlement—observe a number of beliefs. Houses are built facing east for good luck. Doors are not made to face each other. The Ilonggo of Panay, when building a house, take note of the position of the mythical Bakunawa. The months of January and February are best for house-building, while March is not. The beliefs concerning house-building among lowland Filipinos and the cultural communities demonstrate that nature is a living entity. Aside from respecting the natural contours of the land or the quality of the soil when building, the builder pacifies nature by rites or prayers. Ethnic patterns of settlement endure because they are deeply rooted in sensitivity to and respect for the environment. House-building and the establishment of settlements are seen as a way of being one with nature.

 

The Hispanic Tradition

In contrast to the ethnic tradition that accepted the environment as something to be revered and to be in harmony with, the concept of rationally planned space was introduced by Spain. The Ordenanzas of 1573 or the “Prescriptions for the Foundation of Hispanic Colonial Towns” were a codification by Philip II of different instructions given to the conquistadors of the New World. A collection of building laws and zoning requirements that incorporated the experience of building in Latin America as well as the theories of architects from the time of imperial Rome to the Renaissance, the set of 28 ordinances contained practical directions on establishing settlements in the colonies. The heart of the plan was the plaza mayor (main square), a quadrilateral space bounded by streets. From here extended the streets in a grid pattern. Smaller plazas were located at a distance from the main plaza. After the street was laid out, a whole block was assigned for the church and the adjoining convento (parish house). In inland sites, the church was built on high ground and was approached by a flight of steps. In front of it was the plaza, so that it could be seen from a distance. The casa real or town hall was built opposite the church.

Schools and a tribunal or courthouse were later added near the town hall. In towns along the seacoast, the main plaza was near the landing of the port. The church was to be clearly visible from the port and was designed to serve as a defense for it.

The contrast between the Spanish and the Portuguese town plan is striking. Whereas Spanish settlements were rationally planned, Portuguese settlements took advantage of a vista. Important buildings were built on elevated ground or promontories and then connected by streets. The gridiron plan with a plaza was an innovation in 16th-century Europe. The previous era preferred to mass together dwellings beside an important building, usually the church or cathedral.

The rationally and geometrically planned townscape was rooted in part in Philip II’s own view that he was tasked by God to create a Utopia in the newly discovered world. Calling himself a new Solomon, the king sought to create an ideal townscape for God’s glory. The Ordenanzas combined practical guidance and the aesthetics of urban planning.

Spain introduced a hierarchy of settlements. At the apex was the ciudad (city), which in the Philippines was Manila; then came the other ciudades. Below them were the villa (chartered town) and the pueblo (municipality). The center of the pueblo was called cabecera (center) and later, población. The población had a church and convento, and eventually other buildings for civil administration. Below the población were the barrios, ecclesiastically known as visitas, and below them the sitios or settlements consisting of a few houses. Newly organized settlements were called reduccion or rancheria, and ecclesiastically, doctrina.

The transition from the linear settlement patterns or the clustering of indigenous settlements in the Philippines came about through the organization of the reducción; these were compact settlements, arranged in a grid pattern, around a church. The reducción was organized among newly Christianized tribes. In some cases, a settlement was already existing and needed only to be reorganized according to the Spanish tradition. Spanish chroniclers and bureaucrats invariably referred to the reorganization of a settlement as the founding of a pueblo. This should be understood as a legal statement, i.e., that the town was considered part of the colony’s polity, rather than a statement to the effect that before the coming of the Spaniards there were no organized communities in the Philippines. The many indigenous place-names throughout the archipelago attest to the presence of organized communities before the coming of Spain. This is especially true in the Tagalog, Pampango, and Islamic areas. In other cases, dispersed settlements had to be banded as one. The missionary, more than the civil servant, was responsible for organizing many reducciones, which eventually became towns; hence the many saint names among Philippine towns. The missionaries were not always successful at coaxing people to live together. Sickness, fire, or natural calamity would cause them to disperse. Many reducciones were Sunday towns, i.e., the townspeople came to the settlement on Sunday for religious services and instruction and for trade. Then they would return back to their fields.

Native resistance to the reduccion was common. It manifested itself in three ways: the remontados or cimarrones, revolts, and foot dragging. The remontados were Christianized and hispanized Filipinos who took to the hills to escape tribute, forced labor, and injustice. In the Visayas they were called mundos (from Spanish “vagamundos,” vagabonds). Revolts were almost endemic in colonial Philippines, but these would not coalesce into a national revolution until 1896. Earlier revolts may have been spurred by a denunciation of Spanish civilizing efforts and the desire to return to the native way of life. One such uprising occurred in the Visayas in the 1620s. Called the Diwata Revolt, it began when the Visayans were enticed to leave their reducciones by the promise of a life abundant with food and free from taxation and forced labor.

By the mid-18th century, the urban centers of the Philippines, the Central Plains of Luzon, the Southern Tagalog region, the Bicol region, the coastal towns of the Visayas, parts of northern Mindanao, and the tip of the Zamboanga Peninsula were sufficiently hispanized. It took more than a century to reshape the form of colonial communities. Other places took longer to fall under Spanish influence. Batanes and the Cagayan Valley were not evangelized and hispanized until the late 18th century. Although the Spaniards had made inroads into the Cordilleras by the 18th century, their evangelization did not take place until the late 19th century. The island of Negros, named after the dark-skinned Ati tribe, was a missionary outpost from the 17th century, but its hispanization took place only with the sugar boom of the mid–19th century and the migration of many Ilonggo to the island. For centuries, Mindanao was barely under colonial control except for pockets around forts like Zamboanga, Ozamis, Cagayan de Oro, Tandag, and Caraga. By the 19th century, only in northern Mindanao could one find a strong Spanish presence. To speed up the colonization of Mindanao, the colonial government sent military forces to open settlements. Also sent were the undesirables of Manila: prisoners, prostitutes, vagabonds, and political enemies. They were exiled to Surigao and Davao to form the nucleus of new communities. Other places of exile were Paragua in Palawan, Dapitan, Guam, and the Marianas.

The hispanic town plan presupposed an urban economy, where trade more than agriculture was the means of livelihood and where the variety of occupations required various types of buildings. Urbanized space is specialized space, whereas in the ethnic tradition space was multipurpose.

The best-known result of hispanic urbanization is Intramuros, which was actually two settlements, one military, and the other civil. Near the mouth of the river was Fort Santiago, with its own plaza and military buildings. Manila’s plaza mayor was the space fronting the cathedral, presently called Plaza Roma. The main street, Calle Real, stretched from the old Puerta Real at the southern side of the city and passed by the old Jesuit college, San Agustín church and monastery, passed the western flank of the cathedral, all the way to the empty space in front of the moat surrounding Fort Santiago. This space was called Plaza de Armas. Parallel and perpendicular to this main or royal road were the other streets of the city, the more important ones being Calle de Cabildo, Calle de Parian, Calle de Arzobispo, and a circumferential road that followed the contours of the city wall called Muralla. Outside Manila, most provincial capitals, major towns, and cities bear the hispanic mark. A notable example is Vigan, Ilocos Sur. The core of the town revolves around the cathedral and the plaza in front of it, flanked by ecclesiastical and civil buildings. All streets are arranged parallel or perpendicular to the streets surrounding the plaza. Also among those retaining the hispanic plan are Naga and Tiwi in the Bicol region; Pila, Laguna; and the older core of Cebu City, near the cathedral and Fort San Pedro. In some cases, the hispanic town plan has been obscured by the urbanization plans of the Americans. In some instances, the plaza might be smaller than it originally was since the munisipyo or town hall had appropriated land, which was once part of the plaza.

 

The American Colonial Tradition

In 1904 the American architect and city planner Daniel H. Burnham came to the Philippines upon the invitation of Gov-Gen William Cameron Forbes to prepare plans for Manila and Baguio. A disciple of the “City Beautiful” movement, Burnham prepared plans for American cities like Cleveland, Chicago, San Francisco, Baltimore, and Washington DC. Ironically, Burnham’s espousal of the movement and his predilection for the neoclassical idiom placed him in continuity with the hispanic tradition of urbanization, which was rooted in classicism.

Burnham recommended that the street system of the old districts in Manila be maintained, but for the new section outside Intramuros proposed a radial pattern of streets with diagonal thoroughfares linking the city districts. As for Baguio, he proposed a development plan that took the terrain into consideration. In particular, he recommended building around a depressed area, now known as Burnham Park. Burnham stayed briefly in the Philippines and his plans were executed by William Parsons and the Bureau of Public Works. Burnham’s plans were modified by his successors and had not been fully implemented when World War II broke out.

Perhaps more significant in the evolution of communities was the American colonial government’s drive to improve education as a preparation for democracy and self-government, and communication and transportation as a means for improving the economy based on free enterprise, and public health. The lasting legacies of American rule in the townscape are the schools, public markets, hospitals, and city halls. Since ideally the schools were to be provided spacious campuses, they were often built away from the plaza mayor of the hispanic town plan. The school became a magnet that attracted the development of land around it for residential or business use. The city hall at times merely co-opted the casa real but more often than not, was a new building built on the same site or on a new site. Since the school stood for education and the city hall for democracy, these new structures became the centers of development. Improved communication meant the construction or improvement of roads, bridges, lighthouses, wharves, and piers.

Beginning in the 1930s, the Americans fostered migration to Mindanao to ease the congestion in Luzon and the Visayas. Touted as the promised land, Mindanao, especially Cotabato, which was then populated by the Maguindanao, Tboli, and Tiruray, became the destination of waves and waves of migrants who landed in the port of General Santos and, from thence, to their designated homesteads in the hinterlands.

Thus, the American administration laid the foundations of modern urban life characterized by mobility, the quick exchange of goods and ideas, technology, and the amalgamation of populated areas into one urban center. American rule was perceived by some as benevolent and beneficent. However, nationalists were strong in criticizing the abuses of the regime.

The Period of the Republics

In the years following World War II, the Philippines underwent major reconstruction. War had destroyed the means of livelihood all over the country and rural folk were compelled to migrate to the large cities in their search for employment. To meet the needs of a growing urban population, subdivisions began to appear. Earlier subdivisions like those in Singalong and Makati which catered to the middle class, and those in New Manila which accommodated the rich, were not complete communities but integrated themselves with the wider community. A highlight of the 1950s was the development of Philamlife Homes in Quezon City, which was envisioned as a total community by its planners with a community center, a church, a market, recreational facilities, and other amenities. The planners took advantage of the hilly site and created a road system that conformed to the terrain. The housing units designed by Carlos Arguelles enjoyed efficient natural ventilation and had provisions for expansion. The total community concept is found in many subdivisions that mushroomed from the 1960s to the 1990s.

The urban centers continue to attract migrants, but the burgeoning population of cities presents a problem. As population increases, increasing demands are made on the resources of the city, which can strain them to the point of decay.

In the 1950s, particularly during the term of Pres Ramon Magsaysay, migration was encouraged to help relieve the stress on the cities. Also in the 1950s, to meet the needs of low-income groups, the government built low-cost housing projects in Quezon City. The project units were simple, one-story structures with asbestos roofing and wooden jalousies for windows. During the Macapagal period or early 1960s, tenement houses rose in Barrio Punta, Santa Ana, Manila and Bicutan, Rizal. The failure of these tenement houses lay in the absence of necessary infrastructure. Many buildings had no running water and inadequate garbage disposal facilities. A legacy of the Marcos regime are the Bagong Lipunan Sites and Services or BLISS homes, also aimed at lower-income families. Built under the auspices of the Ministry of Human Settlements, they marked an advance over the older tenements as the homes were built to be part of total communities.

Government efforts to provide housing and communities for the urban poor have been inadequate. In spite of the participation of the Church and big business in providing homes, first for their employees and then for the poor, urban housing falls way below what is needed. As a result, many shanties have sprouted in the city. They first appeared after World War II as temporary shelters, but have become a permanent feature in the urban landscape. Large communities of the urban poor in Manila, popularly called “squatters,” are found in Tondo, Quezon City, along the Pasig River, along railroad tracks, and in the reclamation area of the Manila Bay foreshore. Other cities also have their communities of the urban poor.

In the 1980s, a growing Philippine population (placed two decades and a half later at almost 99 million in 2014) and the increasing urbanization of the Philippines put pressure on housing. Catalyzed by the economic boom of the early 1990s, high-rise condominiums, some exceeding 20 stories, began to be built. With the government policy of privatization of non-productive and non-performing government assets, the Bases Conversion and Development Authority (BCDA) was created under Republic Act (RA) 7227, signed into law by Pres Corazon C. Aquino on 12 Mar 1992. The BCDA charter was amended by RA 7917 in 1995, and further amended by RA 94000 in 2007. The opening of Camp John Hay and Fort Bonifacio to redevelopment catalyzed the emergence of new urban spaces based on high-rise buildings. These building are often multiple use, that is, its upper floors or towers are residential and its lower floors or base, called a podium, is for stores, offices, parking and for common areas like gyms, sport centers, function rooms, and other amenities. Many of the podiums are designed with flat waterproof roofs so that a swimming pool, track fields, gardens, and outdoor parks can be built.

This high-rise trend is found in many developments initiated no longer by government but by private developers. Instead of the sprawling subdivisions of the 1960s to the 1980s, the high-rise communities are more compact and minimize occupying the property with built structures. A balance between open spaces, landscape to improve the environment, and built space is planned.

The growing awareness about environment and the human impact on it has pushed for new initiatives in urban planning and construction. “New urbanism” is a term used to refer to an environmentally sensitive town plan and construction scheme that lowers human impact on the environment. Since the burning of fossil fuels has contributed to the degradation of air quality, towns are planned to minimize travel so all the basic resources and institutions of the community, like school, and market are close at hand. In construction, materials that are “green,” that is, have very little adverse environmental impact, are also used.

The subdivisions or gated communities of the previous decades are still being developed but these are often located in the suburbs. A variation of the gated community is the planned resorts and the communities of farms. The former are usually developed beside the sea and the communities of farms are residences in the countryside that have large lots, in which the residents can develop pocket farms. These suburban developments are often purchased to be used as vacation spots by their owners, but with the onset of age and retirement, the resort and farm communities are also attracting the elderly.

Some of these communities are planned along a design theme that appeals to the imagination of the potential buyer seeking the good life. Popular is the Mediterranean style. In mountainous areas are found the Swiss style, characterized by a steep A-frame roof. The names of these new developments often suggest the prevailing and preferred style of the planned community.

While the new urban spaces address the needs of the middle class, often also the employed class—the communities of informal settlers—continue to challenge both the public and the private sector. Some well-known initiatives to address the housing needs of the low-income group are Habitat for Humanity, a foreign-based organization, and Gawad Kalinga, a local organization known for the colorful houses it builds. Both organizations rely on external donations to help finance the housing projects and the active participation of the residents of these houses. Gawad Kalinga goes beyond building or upgrading houses—it also helps communities to develop. It focuses on the empowerment of fathers and training community members in developing marketable skills and setting up their own businesses.  Written by René B. Javellana

A collection of building laws and zoning requirements that incorporated the experience of building in Latin America as well as the theories of architects from the time of imperial Rome to the Renaissance, the set of 28 ordinances contained practical directions on establishing settlements in the colonies. The heart of the plan was the plaza mayor (main square), a quadrilateral space bounded by streets. From here extended the streets in a grid pattern. Smaller plazas were located at a distance from the main plaza. After the street was laid out, a whole block was assigned for the church and the adjoining convento (parish house). In inland sites, the church was built on high ground and was approached by a flight of steps. In front of it was the plaza, so that it could be seen from a distance. The casa real or town hall was built opposite the church.

Schools and a tribunal or courthouse were later added near the town hall. In towns along the seacoast, the main plaza was near the landing of the port. The church was to be clearly visible from the port and was designed to serve as a defense for it.

The contrast between the Spanish and the Portuguese town plan is striking. Whereas Spanish settlements were rationally planned, Portuguese settlements took advantage of a vista. Important buildings were built on elevated ground or promontories and then connected by streets. The gridiron plan with a plaza was an innovation in 16th-century Europe. The previous era preferred to mass together dwellings beside an important building, usually the church or cathedral.

The rationally and geometrically planned townscape was rooted in part in Philip II’s own view that he was tasked by God to create a Utopia in the newly discovered world. Calling himself a new Solomon, the king sought to create an ideal townscape for God’s glory. The Ordenanzas combined practical guidance and the aesthetics of urban planning.

Spain introduced a hierarchy of settlements. At the apex was the ciudad (city), which in the Philippines was Manila; then came the other ciudades. Below them were the villa (chartered town) and the pueblo (municipality). The center of the pueblo was called cabecera (center) and later, población. The población had a church and convento, and eventually other buildings for civil administration. Below the población were the barrios, ecclesiastically known as visitas, and below them the sitios or settlements consisting of a few houses. Newly organized settlements were called reduccion or rancheria, and ecclesiastically, doctrina.

The transition from the linear settlement patterns or the clustering of indigenous settlements in the Philippines came about through the organization of the reducción; these were compact settlements, arranged in a grid pattern, around a church. The reducción was organized among newly Christianized tribes. In some cases, a settlement was already existing and needed only to be reorganized according to the Spanish tradition. Spanish chroniclers and bureaucrats invariably referred to the reorganization of a settlement as the founding of a pueblo. This should be understood as a legal statement, i.e., that the town was considered part of the colony’s polity, rather than a statement to the effect that before the coming of the Spaniards there were no organized communities in the Philippines. The many indigenous place-names throughout the archipelago attest to the presence of organized communities before the coming of Spain. This is especially true in the Tagalog, Pampango, and Islamic areas. In other cases, dispersed settlements had to be banded as one. The missionary, more than the civil servant, was responsible for organizing many reducciones, which eventually became towns; hence the many saint names among Philippine towns. The missionaries were not always successful at coaxing people to live together. Sickness, fire, or natural calamity would cause them to disperse. Many reducciones were Sunday towns, i.e., the townspeople came to the settlement on Sunday for religious services and instruction and for trade. Then they would return back to their fields.

Native resistance to the reduccion was common. It manifested itself in three ways: the remontados or cimarrones, revolts, and foot dragging. The remontados were Christianized and hispanized Filipinos who took to the hills to escape tribute, forced labor, and injustice. In the Visayas they were called mundos (from Spanish “vagamundos,” vagabonds). Revolts were almost endemic in colonial Philippines, but these would not coalesce into a national revolution until 1896. Earlier revolts may have been spurred by a denunciation of Spanish civilizing efforts and the desire to return to the native way of life. One such uprising occurred in the Visayas in the 1620s. Called the Diwata Revolt, it began when the Visayans were enticed to leave their reducciones by the promise of a life abundant with food and free from taxation and forced labor.

By the mid-18th century, the urban centers of the Philippines, the Central Plains of Luzon, the Southern Tagalog region, the Bicol region, the coastal towns of the Visayas, parts of northern Mindanao, and the tip of the Zamboanga Peninsula were sufficiently hispanized. It took more than a century to reshape the form of colonial communities. Other places took longer to fall under Spanish influence. Batanes and the Cagayan Valley were not evangelized and hispanized until the late 18th century. Although the Spaniards had made inroads into the Cordilleras by the 18th century, their evangelization did not take place until the late 19th century. The island of Negros, named after the dark-skinned Ati tribe, was a missionary outpost from the 17th century, but its hispanization took place only with the sugar boom of the mid–19th century and the migration of many Ilonggo to the island. For centuries, Mindanao was barely under colonial control except for pockets around forts like Zamboanga, Ozamis, Cagayan de Oro, Tandag, and Caraga. By the 19th century, only in northern Mindanao could one find a strong Spanish presence. To speed up the colonization of Mindanao, the colonial government sent military forces to open settlements. Also sent were the undesirables of Manila: prisoners, prostitutes, vagabonds, and political enemies. They were exiled to Surigao and Davao to form the nucleus of new communities. Other places of exile were Paragua in Palawan, Dapitan, Guam, and the Marianas.

The hispanic town plan presupposed an urban economy, where trade more than agriculture was the means of livelihood and where the variety of occupations required various types of buildings. Urbanized space is specialized space, whereas in the ethnic tradition space was multipurpose.

The best-known result of hispanic urbanization is Intramuros, which was actually two settlements, one military, and the other civil. Near the mouth of the river was Fort Santiago, with its own plaza and military buildings. Manila’s plaza mayor was the space fronting the cathedral, presently called Plaza Roma. The main street, Calle Real, stretched from the old Puerta Real at the southern side of the city and passed by the old Jesuit college, San Agustín church and monastery, passed the western flank of the cathedral, all the way to the empty space in front of the moat surrounding Fort Santiago. This space was called Plaza de Armas. Parallel and perpendicular to this main or royal road were the other streets of the city, the more important ones being Calle de Cabildo, Calle de Parian, Calle de Arzobispo, and a circumferential road that followed the contours of the city wall called Muralla. Outside Manila, most provincial capitals, major towns, and cities bear the hispanic mark. A notable example is Vigan, Ilocos Sur. The core of the town revolves around the cathedral and the plaza in front of it, flanked by ecclesiastical and civil buildings. All streets are arranged parallel or perpendicular to the streets surrounding the plaza. Also among those retaining the hispanic plan are Naga and Tiwi in the Bicol region; Pila, Laguna; and the older core of Cebu City, near the cathedral and Fort San Pedro. In some cases, the hispanic town plan has been obscured by the urbanization plans of the Americans. In some instances, the plaza might be smaller than it originally was since the munisipyo or town hall had appropriated land, which was once part of the plaza.

article.value: The American Colonial Tradition

In 1904 the American architect and city planner Daniel H. Burnham came to the Philippines upon the invitation of Gov-Gen William Cameron Forbes to prepare plans for Manila and Baguio. A disciple of the “City Beautiful” movement, Burnham prepared plans for American cities like Cleveland, Chicago, San Francisco, Baltimore, and Washington DC. Ironically, Burnham’s espousal of the movement and his predilection for the neoclassical idiom placed him in continuity with the hispanic tradition of urbanization, which was rooted in classicism.

Burnham recommended that the street system of the old districts in Manila be maintained, but for the new section outside Intramuros proposed a radial pattern of streets with diagonal thoroughfares linking the city districts. As for Baguio, he proposed a development plan that took the terrain into consideration. In particular, he recommended building around a depressed area, now known as Burnham Park. Burnham stayed briefly in the Philippines and his plans were executed by William Parsons and the Bureau of Public Works. Burnham’s plans were modified by his successors and had not been fully implemented when World War II broke out.

Perhaps more significant in the evolution of communities was the American colonial government’s drive to improve education as a preparation for democracy and self-government, and communication and transportation as a means for improving the economy based on free enterprise, and public health. The lasting legacies of American rule in the townscape are the schools, public markets, hospitals, and city halls. Since ideally the schools were to be provided spacious campuses, they were often built away from the plaza mayor of the hispanic town plan. The school became a magnet that attracted the development of land around it for residential or business use. The city hall at times merely co-opted the casa real but more often than not, was a new building built on the same site or on a new site. Since the school stood for education and the city hall for democracy, these new structures became the centers of development. Improved communication meant the construction or improvement of roads, bridges, lighthouses, wharves, and piers.

Beginning in the 1930s, the Americans fostered migration to Mindanao to ease the congestion in Luzon and the Visayas. Touted as the promised land, Mindanao, especially Cotabato, which was then populated by the Maguindanao, Tboli, and Tiruray, became the destination of waves and waves of migrants who landed in the port of General Santos and, from thence, to their designated homesteads in the hinterlands.

Thus, the American administration laid the foundations of modern urban life characterized by mobility, the quick exchange of goods and ideas, technology, and the amalgamation of populated areas into one urban center. American rule was perceived by some as benevolent and beneficent. However, nationalists were strong in criticizing the abuses of the regime.
The Period of the Republics

In the years following World War II, the Philippines underwent major reconstruction. War had destroyed the means of livelihood all over the country and rural folk were compelled to migrate to the large cities in their search for employment. To meet the needs of a growing urban population, subdivisions began to appear. Earlier subdivisions like those in Singalong and Makati which catered to the middle class, and those in New Manila which accommodated the rich, were not complete communities but integrated themselves with the wider community. A highlight of the 1950s was the development of Philamlife Homes in Quezon City, which was envisioned as a total community by its planners with a community center, a church, a market, recreational facilities, and other amenities. The planners took advantage of the hilly site and created a road system that conformed to the terrain. The housing units designed by Carlos Arguelles enjoyed efficient natural ventilation and had provisions for expansion. The total community concept is found in many subdivisions that mushroomed from the 1960s to the 1990s.

The urban centers continue to attract migrants, but the burgeoning population of cities presents a problem. As population increases, increasing demands are made on the resources of the city, which can strain them to the point of decay.

In the 1950s, particularly during the term of Pres Ramon Magsaysay, migration was encouraged to help relieve the stress on the cities. Also in the 1950s, to meet the needs of low-income groups, the government built low-cost housing projects in Quezon City. The project units were simple, one-story structures with asbestos roofing and wooden jalousies for windows. During the Macapagal period or early 1960s, tenement houses rose in Barrio Punta, Santa Ana, Manila and Bicutan, Rizal. The failure of these tenement houses lay in the absence of necessary infrastructure. Many buildings had no running water and inadequate garbage disposal facilities. A legacy of the Marcos regime are the Bagong Lipunan Sites and Services or BLISS homes, also aimed at lower-income families. Built under the auspices of the Ministry of Human Settlements, they marked an advance over the older tenements as the homes were built to be part of total communities.

Government efforts to provide housing and communities for the urban poor have been inadequate. In spite of the participation of the Church and big business in providing homes, first for their employees and then for the poor, urban housing falls way below what is needed. As a result, many shanties have sprouted in the city. They first appeared after World War II as temporary shelters, but have become a permanent feature in the urban landscape. Large communities of the urban poor in Manila, popularly called “squatters,” are found in Tondo, Quezon City, along the Pasig River, along railroad tracks, and in the reclamation area of the Manila Bay foreshore. Other cities also have their communities of the urban poor.

In the 1980s, a growing Philippine population (placed two decades and a half later at almost 99 million in 2014) and the increasing urbanization of the Philippines put pressure on housing. Catalyzed by the economic boom of the early 1990s, high-rise condominiums, some exceeding 20 stories, began to be built. With the government policy of privatization of non-productive and non-performing government assets, the Bases Conversion and Development Authority (BCDA) was created under Republic Act (RA) 7227, signed into law by Pres Corazon C. Aquino on 12 Mar 1992. The BCDA charter was amended by RA 7917 in 1995, and further amended by RA 94000 in 2007. The opening of Camp John Hay and Fort Bonifacio to redevelopment catalyzed the emergence of new urban spaces based on high-rise buildings. These building are often multiple use, that is, its upper floors or towers are residential and its lower floors or base, called a podium, is for stores, offices, parking and for common areas like gyms, sport centers, function rooms, and other amenities. Many of the podiums are designed with flat waterproof roofs so that a swimming pool, track fields, gardens, and outdoor parks can be built.

This high-rise trend is found in many developments initiated no longer by government but by private developers. Instead of the sprawling subdivisions of the 1960s to the 1980s, the high-rise communities are more compact and minimize occupying the property with built structures. A balance between open spaces, landscape to improve the environment, and built space is planned.

The growing awareness about environment and the human impact on it has pushed for new initiatives in urban planning and construction. “New urbanism” is a term used to refer to an environmentally sensitive town plan and construction scheme that lowers human impact on the environment. Since the burning of fossil fuels has contributed to the degradation of air quality, towns are planned to minimize travel so all the basic resources and institutions of the community, like school, and market are close at hand. In construction, materials that are “green,” that is, have very little adverse environmental impact, are also used.

The subdivisions or gated communities of the previous decades are still being developed but these are often located in the suburbs. A variation of the gated community is the planned resorts and the communities of farms. The former are usually developed beside the sea and the communities of farms are residences in the countryside that have large lots, in which the residents can develop pocket farms. These suburban developments are often purchased to be used as vacation spots by their owners, but with the onset of age and retirement, the resort and farm communities are also attracting the elderly.

Some of these communities are planned along a design theme that appeals to the imagination of the potential buyer seeking the good life. Popular is the Mediterranean style. In mountainous areas are found the Swiss style, characterized by a steep A-frame roof. The names of these new developments often suggest the prevailing and preferred style of the planned community.

While the new urban spaces address the needs of the middle class, often also the employed class—the communities of informal settlers—continue to challenge both the public and the private sector. Some well-known initiatives to address the housing needs of the low-income group are Habitat for Humanity, a foreign-based organization, and Gawad Kalinga, a local organization known for the colorful houses it builds. Both organizations rely on external donations to help finance the housing projects and the active participation of the residents of these houses. Gawad Kalinga goes beyond building or upgrading houses—it also helps communities to develop. It focuses on the empowerment of fathers and training community members in developing marketable skills and setting up their own businesses.
